headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Xerox Corporation First Quarter 2016 Earnings Release Conference Call hosted by Ursula Burns, Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer. She is joined by Leslie Varon, Vice President and Interim Chief Financial Off
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the Xerox Corporation First Quarter 2016 Earnings Release Conference Call hosted by Ursula Burns, Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer. She is joined by Leslie Varon, Vice President and Interim Chief Financial Officer.
During this call, Xerox executives will refer to slides that are available on the web at www.xerox.com/investor. At the request of Xerox Corporation, today's conference call is being recorded. Other recording and/or rebroadcasting of this call are prohibited without the expressed permission of Xerox. [Operator Instructions] During this conference call, Xerox executives will make comments that contain forward-looking statements, which, by their nature, address matters that are in the future and are uncertain. Actual future financial results may be materially different than those expressed herein. 
At this time, I would like to turn the meeting over to Ms. Burns. Ms. Burns, you may begin.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining us. I am pleased to report that at the end of the first quarter, we are on track to deliver on our 3 commitments for the year: meeting our guidance, reaching the first year target for our strategic transformation pr
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining us. I am pleased to report that at the end of the first quarter, we are on track to deliver on our 3 commitments for the year: meeting our guidance, reaching the first year target for our strategic transformation program and completing our separation into 2 companies. I'll begin with an update on our progress on the new path forward for Xerox before turning to first quarter results. 
In January, we announced plans to separate into 2 independent publicly-traded companies, one comprising our Document Technology and Document Outsourcing businesses, and the other our Business Process Outsourcing business. Both will be Fortune 500 scale companies that are leaders in their respective industry. 
Further demonstrating our commitment to driving shareholder value, we concurrently announced a strategic transformation program to deliver $2.4 billion in cumulative savings over 3 years, which includes both ongoing and incremental initiatives to enhance productivity and efficiency. We are looking at all aspects of our business to make them more agile and competitive and expect to achieve $700 million in annualized savings this year. Together, these actions will create 2 focused companies that have strategies, talent and the organizational and capital structures needed to compete in their markets. 
We are making progress on both of these initiatives and I am confident that we're making the right steps to best position each company for the future. We've had positive feedback on our plans. Over the last few months, we've been talking to employees, clients and partners regularly about the benefits of the separation and what it means for them. Our clients see the benefits of increased focus and responsiveness to the market. 
In fact, I met with the executive teams of 2 major clients in the past couple of weeks, both in the top 75 of the Fortune 500 and both expressed their positive view and our employees tell us they are excited to be part of the journey and to work for that are innovative and leading in their industries. 
During the last 3 months, we have made substantial progress in building strong operational and financial foundations for both companies. We formed a program management office or PMO, that is driving the separation and strategic transformation initiatives, reporting to an executive steering committee that I lead. The PMO working with the business teams is designing operating models and organizational structures. It is also responsible for structuring the separation transaction and a designing the optimal capital and legal structures. We are also taking a close look at the business strategies for both Document Technology and BPO to ensure they are fully optimized. 
We have identified a number of ways to sharpen each business strategy and improve execution. We are completing this analysis and we'll develop detailed action plans to capture the highest value opportunities. Some of that implementation will begin this year with more to come postseparation. 
Many of you have asked about milestone decisions regarding leadership and financials. These are critical decisions that require a thoughtful process. While I can't answer all of your questions at this stage, I can share a few insights on where we stand. With regards to the leadership of the 2 companies, our search is well underway and we have high-quality candidates for each key executive role. While the timing for completing the hiring process for various senior roles is very difficult to predict, we're targeting to fulfill the top roles by mid year. 
In addition to management teams, we are reviewing candidates to fill the additional boards created as a result of the separation. On financials. The big milestone is the filing of our initial Form 10 registration statement with the SEC. We are on track to do that in July in line with our goal of completing the separation by year-end. We've decided that the optimal yay to execute the separation is through our tax-free spin-off of our BPO business. The Form 10 will describe the transaction in detail and provide more information on the BPO company. 
We have also quantified the cost associated with the separation and the first year of the strategic transformation program. We expect to incur onetime separation costs of $200 million to $250 million and restructuring costs of $300 million. Leslie will provide further details on this shortly. So all in all, very good progress on these initiatives. We're on track to launch 2 companies at year-end that will have the right strategies, the right structures and the right leaders. 
With that said, I want to emphasize that we are managing these programs to ensure our executive team and employees remain focused on serving our clients with excellence and delivering our 2016 plans. So let's talk about how we're doing on that front. 
In the first quarter of 2015, we delivered adjusted EPS of $0.22 within our guidance range, GAAP EPS from continuing operations was $0.03. Total revenue of $4.3 billion was down 4% or 3% in constant currency, reflecting growth in our Document Outsourcing and BPO business offset by continued revenue pressures in our Document Technology segment. Operating margin of 7.2% declined 130 basis points year-over-year. 
In Services revenue, growth improved and margin increased modestly compared to last year. Document Technology revenue continues to be impacted by the weakness in developing markets and currency negatively impacted Doc Tech margin. As a result of these factors, we have accelerated our cost-reduction initiatives resulting in a sizable restructuring charge. We expect to realize the benefits of these actions beginning in the second quarter. 
During the quarter, we also continue to strengthen our portfolio with new products and offerings that showcase our innovation. Here are a few examples. In the healthcare market, we launched Xerox health outcomes solutions, a full of livestock cycle population health management solution, designed to help providers adapt to value-based contracts. 
The centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services have set a requirement that by 2018, 50% of all payments must be value-based, meaning providers are compensated for a healthy outcome rather than each service provided. According to a survey that we had sponsored, healthcare providers and payers need to significantly accelerate their efforts to adapt to this standard. So we see a big opportunity for this product. 
Our transportation team introduced the Go Denver and Go LA mobile app to help residents and tourists make transportation choices more easily and effectively. Commuters in Denver and Los Angeles can use Xerox-powered apps to search for the cheapest, fastest and most sustainable way to move around these cities. We expanded the capabilities of our ConnectKey platform targeting the large office market. This new and refreshed collection of apps and tools boosts workplace productivity by tightly integrating our 14 ConnectKey multifunction devices with Cloud-hosted services and mobile communication technologies. It is innovative -- innovations like these that enable us to maintain our #1 market share position in MPS. 
And for our Graphic Communications customers. We introduced 2 new next-generation inkjet presses, the Xerox Brenda HBU production and the Xerox 2400 inkjet press. These represent the first of a new series of innovative inkjet products that will enhance our high-end printing offerings. We look forward to ramping up sales later this year.
Looking to cash flow. We used $25 million in our cash from operations, which is in line with seasonality and ended the quarter with a healthy cash balance of $1.2 billion. Bottom line, we met our guidance and are confident that we're taking the right steps to achieve full year objectives. Some of our underlying results were mixed and we are pulling all levers within our control to successfully navigate in a challenging market environment and best position our business for the future. 
I will turn it over to Leslie, who will provide more detail on our financial results and 2016 guidance.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ursula, and good morning, everyone. I'll start by walking through the income statement and then discuss guidance before handing it back to Ursula to wrap up. Before I get started, I'll remind you that the information I'm sharing reflects the repor
componenttext:
Thanks, Ursula, and good morning, everyone. I'll start by walking through the income statement and then discuss guidance before handing it back to Ursula to wrap up. Before I get started, I'll remind you that the information I'm sharing reflects the reporting revisions we announced last quarter. 
Total revenue of $4.3 billion and adjusted earnings of $0.22 were within our expectations. Services delivered modest profit growth while Document Technology declined due to revenue and transaction currency headwind and cost reduction timing. Revenues in the quarter were down 4% at actual currency and 3% at constant currency, an improvement from the 5% constant currency decline in quarter 4. Services' top line was up 2% at constant currency with growth in both the growth Document Outsourcing and BPO. Document Technology declined 9% at constant currency and drove the overall revenue decline. I'll speak more about both segments in a moment.
Gross margin of 30.3% was down 130 basis points year-over-year, driven by declines in Document Technology and a greater mix of Services, which structurally has a lower gross margin. Our D&E was lower by $8 million year-over-year and SAG was down $35 million or 4%. Good expense reduction in absolute terms but not sufficient to offset growth in gross margin declines resulting in operating margin of 7.2%, down 130 basis points year-over-year and an 18% operating profit decline. 
Adjusted other net expense was higher by $8 million year-over-year, driven by higher litigation reserves while equity income of $37 million in the quarter was up $3 million year-over-year. Our first quarter adjusted tax rate of 22.5% was below our guidance range of 26% to 28%, benefiting our earnings by about $0.01, and reflecting higher foreign tax credits as well as the geographic mix of topics. Bottom line, adjusted earnings of $0.22 was within our guidance of $0.20 $0.01 at $0.24 and was $0.02 lower, driven by Document Technology. 
Taking a closer look at Services. Results in the quarter were largely in line with expectations. Good top line growth continued in Document Outsourcing and BPO was up slightly. Margin improved modestly year-over-year. Together, those 2 drove 2% segment profit growth. Services revenue grew 1% or 2% at constant currency. BPO was up 1% at constant currency as growth from acquisitions and new contract ramp, particularly in healthcare, more than half said headwinds in commercial from volumes declined in lost business. Our decision and subsequent agreements with California and Montana not to complete the Health Enterprise Medicaid platform implementation was a revenue headwind but was partially offset by last year's first quarter California Health Enterprise adjustments. 
Good growth continues in Document Outsourcing, up 5% at constant currency, driven by strong Xerox Partner Print Services growth as well as strong equipment revenue growth in large enterprise accounts following strong 2015 signings.
Total signings in the quarter were down 11% year-over-year but up 9% for the trailing 12 months. The year-over-year decline was driven by fewer renewal opportunities this quarter. The Total Contract Value of our new business signings was up 6% year-over-year, driven by good growth in public sector. 
Our renewal rate in the quarter was quite strong in 89% so at the high-end at our 85% to 90% range. Services segment margin was 7.7%, up 10 basis points year-over-year. Improvements in Government Healthcare, including the Health Enterprise decisions we made last year, were, partially offset by margin declines, driven in part by customer care where we have operational and efficiency opportunities. We've hired 2 well respected leaders from the industry and they're beginning to implement changes to drive improved results. 
Document Outsourcing margins were down modestly in the quarter remained strong and well above the Services margin. So good progress on growth and we're taking additional action to drive further margin improvement. I'll now turn to Document Technology.
This was a challenging quarter for the Document Technology business with economic currency and product cycle headwinds. Revenue was down 9% at constant currency in line with quarter 4. Equipment revenue was down 14% year-over-year, including much higher declines in developing markets, especially the Middle East and Russia. Supplies revenue was down 7% year-over-year, much better than quarter 4 as channel inventory returned to more normalized levels. 
When we include Document Outsourcing with Document Technology, the revenue decline continued at about 5%, which largely reflects the current revenue profile of the new Document Technology company postseparation. Turning to activity. Within entry, A4 color MSD growth was up 1%, but overall results were pressured by developing markets. Mid-range color MSPs also grew 1%, driven by growth in Document Outsourcing. We're expecting the new I series products launched in March to result in better mid-range growth as we move through 2016. 
High-end was the strongest performing product area with color installs up 56%, including strong growth in the entry production color product in iGen and we're looking forward to the upcoming group of printing trade show in early June, where we'll be highlighting a number of new exciting production printing products especially in production inkjets. 
Document Technology margins of 10.2% was down 250 basis points year-over-year. As you know, quarter 1 is seasonally weak. Approximately 100 basis points of the year-over-year decline was driven by transaction currency. At March 31 rates, we expect very modest transaction currency impacts in quarter 2 and for the balance of the year. The equipment price declines in the quarter remained within our historic range of 5% to 10%. 
The quarter 1 margin also reflects productivity, only partially offsetting the impact of revenue declines. Following lower restructuring in the second half of 2015, we significantly ramped up restructuring in quarter 1 and expect to capture incremental benefits from the strategic transformation program as we move through the year. Despite the first quarter challenges, we're confident that trend in both revenue and margin will improve, benefiting from recent product launches and cost actions. 
Moving to cash flow. Operating cash flow with the use of $25 million in the quarter and in line with our expectations, reflecting lower net income, a Health Enterprise settlement payment, and normal working capital seasonality following a strong close to 2015. Investing cash flows were a use of $125 million and included $72 million spent on CapEx, a $52 million payment to Atos for the final working capital work adjustment for 2015 ITO divestiture and $18 million invested for a small technology acquisition. 
Cash flow from financing was a $42 million use and include $77 million for preferred and common stock dividend. In the quarter, we retired a $700 million senior note and refinanced it with a senior unsecured bank loan. Our cash balance at the end of the quarter was $1.2 billion and continues to provide us flexibility as we move through 2016. 
Turning to our capital structure and capital allocation. We ended quarter 1 with $7.4 billion of debt, roughly in line with our year-end debt level. Applying 7 to 1 leverage to our customer financing assets, our allocated financing debt at the end of Q1 was $3.9 billion, leaving core debt of $3.5 billion. We continue to manage our capital structure to maintain credit metrics consistent with our investment-grade credit rating. 
Now to touch on capital allocation. We have a strong shareholder returns track record, having returned over 70% of free cash flow to our shareholders since 2011. Building on this, we announced last quarter an 11% increase to our common dividend effective with the dividend payable on April 29 of this year. We did not repurchase any shares in the quarter. 
Turning to the next slide, I'll share with you our second quarter earnings expectations and update date our full-year guidance to incorporate the separation related costs and higher restructuring, which Ursula just discussed earlier. For the second quarter, we expect adjusted earnings in the range of $0.24 to $0.26 and GAAP earnings of $0.06 to $0.08. For the full year, we are reaffirming our revenue guidance of a 2% to 4% constant currency decline and adjusted earnings guidance of $1.10 to $1.20 per share. 
We are maintain in our segment revenue growth and margin segment changes for both Services and Technology. We're adjusting our full-year GAAP guidance to incorporate the $200 million to $250 million of separation costs that Ursula previously discussed. Separation costs include professional fees, transaction costs and operational separation investment. We haven't yet included any tax charges to prepare for the separation. We plan to share additional separation details in July after we file the initial Form 10.
As Ursula mentioned, we're accelerating our strategic transformation initiative and therefore, expect to incur higher restructuring and related costs. We now expect to spend $300 million for the full year, $100 million more than we previously guided. And in quarter 2, we expect to incur about $100 million in the restructuring costs. Including the separation costs and the higher restructuring costs, we now expect full-year GAAP EPS of $0.45 to $0.55 per share. 
We're adjusting our cash flow guidance to reflect both the cash separation costs and higher restructuring. We began this year with operating cash flow guidance of $1.3 billion to $1.5 billion. We indicated at the time that our guidance included $200 million of restructuring costs, but did not yet contemplate separation costs. Factoring in cash separation costs of $200 million to $250 million and the $100 million higher restructuring costs, we now expect operating cash flow of $950 million to $1.2 billion. 
We are also modestly increasing our CapEx guidance to $350 million to incorporate expenditures resulting in updated free cash flow guidance of $600 million to $850 million. This is an unusual year with separation-related investment pressuring cash flow well below normal levels. We're revising our capital allocation expectations to reflect our updated free cash flow guidance. 
Dividends will be approximately $350 million for the year and reflect the 11% increase. We expect acquisition investments will approximate $100 million and we'll use the remainder of our free cash flow to reduced debt as we seek to optimize the capital structures of the 2 companies. Share repurchases have been a significant part of our capital deployment during the past few years, including $1.3 billion last year as we returned to shareholders a large portion of our strong cash flow, including the ITO divestiture proceeds. This year, given the separation, we don't plan to repurchase any shares. 
So in summary, a mixed quarter but we met our guidance and remain committed to delivering our full-year objectives with accelerated strategic transformation benefits to protect the bottom line. 
With that, I'll hand it back to Ursula to wrap up.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Leslie. To recap, at the end of the first quarter, we are on track to deliver on our plan for the year. Our first quarter results were in line with expectations. We saw a good performance on key measures in our Services business, and continued
componenttext:
Thank you, Leslie. To recap, at the end of the first quarter, we are on track to deliver on our plan for the year. Our first quarter results were in line with expectations. We saw a good performance on key measures in our Services business, and continued pressure in our Document Technology business. We're taking decisive actions to address our challenges and improve margins, including accelerating our cost optimization efforts in line with the strategic transformation program that we announced in January. 
Looking ahead, we're focused on our 3 commitments. Meeting our guidance, reaching the targets for our strategic transformation program and completing our separation. We remain confident that we'll do so. 
With that, let me turn it over to Jennifer.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think just focus a little bit on your question, yes. What we're seeing in the business and the actions that we're taking to assure that we -- when we separate these 2 businesses and obviously, in 2016 as well, that we get the cost structure and operatin
componenttext: I think just focus a little bit on your question, yes. What we're seeing in the business and the actions that we're taking to assure that we -- when we separate these 2 businesses and obviously, in 2016 as well, that we get the cost structure and operating model right for these 2 businesses. When we look at restructuring and all of the strategic transformation programs, it's focused on cleaning out the infrastructure of the business. So spans and layers, everything from spends and layers to how we approach the market from a selling perspective, how we approach the market from a supply chain perspective, et cetera. All in leading our cost and efficient operation, not to impact our revenue flow or how we service our customers. So I -- and I think that what we've shown in the first quarter is the ability to actually do that to drive restructuring and kind of fall in our expectation range and hold up our full-year commitments in both BPO and in Doc Tech, and in the full company perspective. So I think you're right. We're trying to balance all of these things and a lot of stuff going on, but I think we're keeping our eye on the ball and delivering fairly well in line with separation by the way, we'll do that by the end of the year.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So, Ananda. It's Leslie. So first of all, with regard to the $700 million of annualized savings this year, it's consistent with what we had previously said and underscores our commitment to deliver adjusted earnings of $1.10 to $1.20 this year. We, as you
componenttext: So, Ananda. It's Leslie. So first of all, with regard to the $700 million of annualized savings this year, it's consistent with what we had previously said and underscores our commitment to deliver adjusted earnings of $1.10 to $1.20 this year. We, as you noted, increase the restructuring. Quite frankly, we did that in order to underscore our ability to deliver the range even though the Document Technology revenue have begun the year a bit softer than we would have liked. So this year, we don't anticipate investing any of the $700 million. Any investment of restructuring savings are ahead of us not in 2015. With regard to the tax-free spend, I think what we've said is that it's tax-free from a federal income tax perspective. Any tax the synergies associated with the spin or any onetime tax costs associated with the spend will explicitly identified post the Form 10 filing. So as we get to quarter 2 earnings announcement at the end of July.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So George, what we're going to do is on the synergies is we're going to try to hold that conversation until the middle of the year where we get a better grasp on what they are specifically and not kind of dribble it out. So -- but, some of the general dis
componenttext: So George, what we're going to do is on the synergies is we're going to try to hold that conversation until the middle of the year where we get a better grasp on what they are specifically and not kind of dribble it out. So -- but, some of the general dissynergies are what you call independent company cost the synergy, setting up a board those kinds of things general bucket. But we don't want to get to ahead of ourselves piecemeal it out, we'll have some very specific clarity in the middle of the year when we form -- file some of the Form 10 documents and start to communicate more. But think about setting up 2 independent companies and the structures that you need for that.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So George, it's Leslie. If I could just add on to that a little bit. We certainly expect that over time, the benefits from our strategic transformation will significantly outweigh any of the dissynergies associated with running 2 companies. As you know, a
componenttext: So George, it's Leslie. If I could just add on to that a little bit. We certainly expect that over time, the benefits from our strategic transformation will significantly outweigh any of the dissynergies associated with running 2 companies. As you know, as Ursula just mentioned, there's certainly public company costs. But when you look at dissynergies that typically impact other companies, there will be less that we face because we haven't done a tremendous amount of integration of BPO with what was the Doc Tech organization.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Ursula or Leslie, Services margins in the quarter came in below the full year guidance range, which means there will be a catch-up event that will have to happen later in the year. Can you discuss your expectations for the cadence of Services margin i
componenttext: And Ursula or Leslie, Services margins in the quarter came in below the full year guidance range, which means there will be a catch-up event that will have to happen later in the year. Can you discuss your expectations for the cadence of Services margin improvement through the year and what those drivers are?

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Think about expansion throughout the year, quarter by quarter, that's the expectation of the plan. Services margins came in at about where we would've expected them to come in. We expect them to be at the lower end of our full year ranges in the first qua
componenttext: Think about expansion throughout the year, quarter by quarter, that's the expectation of the plan. Services margins came in at about where we would've expected them to come in. We expect them to be at the lower end of our full year ranges in the first quarter, it's seasonably lighter quarter for us in general and second quarter will be better, third and fourth, like that. We are fairly confident of coming in and that's why we're reiterating the guidance on our Services margin for the full year and by the way, for our EPS for the adjusted EPS for the full year, our cash flow we've adjusted down on our Doc Tech, we've reiterated as well. So it's kind of come in where we expect it.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So George, a couple of things. You know we took $126 million of restructuring charges in quarter 1. That should benefit both businesses as we move through the year. We've announced another $100 million of restructuring in quarter 2, which should also bene
componenttext: So George, a couple of things. You know we took $126 million of restructuring charges in quarter 1. That should benefit both businesses as we move through the year. We've announced another $100 million of restructuring in quarter 2, which should also benefit the margin of both businesses as we move through the year. We called out a specific weakness in quarter 1 in customer care where we have new leadership that we've recently brought into the company and we do expect to be able to address some of those operational and efficiency challenges as we move through the year. So we're pretty optimistic about delivering the 8% to 9.5% Services segment margin for the year.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, George.
componenttext: Thanks, George.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Shannon Cross from Cross Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Shannon Cross from Cross Research.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to dig a bit into the Doc Tech margins and especially given the over -- this is a Drupa year and then maybe some -- I would assume some timing challenges when the expenses were driven by reverses [ph], coming through the commercial print side. So
componenttext: I wanted to dig a bit into the Doc Tech margins and especially given the over -- this is a Drupa year and then maybe some -- I would assume some timing challenges when the expenses were driven by reverses [ph], coming through the commercial print side. So when we think about the 12% to 14% operating margin targets that I assume you guys are holding to here, and you were at 10% this quarter, I know there's a lot of restructuring going on. But can you maybe give us some idea of how we balance the need to invest in Drupa, which happens every 4 years versus sort of the timing of the cost cuts coming through since you did lay off a pretty significant amount of people in the first quarter.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I'll start and then Leslie will chime in. And I just want to start with a level of clarity about what we are reiterating. We are absolutely reiterating full year Doc Tech margins in the 12% to 14% range. That is, we are confident that we can deliv
componenttext: Yes. So I'll start and then Leslie will chime in. And I just want to start with a level of clarity about what we are reiterating. We are absolutely reiterating full year Doc Tech margins in the 12% to 14% range. That is, we are confident that we can deliver that. We are also reiterating Services margin in the 8% to 9.5% range. We're reiterating revenue -- our revenue guidance and we're reiterating our adjusted EPS guidance. All 3 -- all of those things, 4 or 5 I just mentioned are not changed at all. We did have a light -- lower delivery of margin in the first quarter for Doc Tech, but we are very confident Drupa, other product launches, timing of our saves, the flow and currency and how it affects our margins, they will all come out in the next 3 quarters, delivering somewhere between the 12% and 14% margins that we spoke about. Leslie can speak more on this as well.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Shannon, just to reiterate. The transaction currency cost us about 100 basis points year-over-year in terms of the Doc Tech margin. So Doc Tech margin of 10.2%, down 250 basis points. 100 of that was transaction currency. We believe that $19 million pr
componenttext: So Shannon, just to reiterate. The transaction currency cost us about 100 basis points year-over-year in terms of the Doc Tech margin. So Doc Tech margin of 10.2%, down 250 basis points. 100 of that was transaction currency. We believe that $19 million pressure in quarter 1 turns to essentially negligible in quarter 2. And when you add on top of that, the restructuring benefits that we expect to capture from the restructuring that we did in quarter 1 and that we're doing more of in quarter 2, we're very, very confident of being able to get to the 12% and 14% range for the year. With regard to Drupa, you're absolutely right. It is an investment that we make once every 4 years, but it is relatively modest compared to for instance, the transaction currency headwinds that we faced in Q1.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ursula, can you just talk a little bit about philosophically anything that has changed how you think about the capital structure of the 2 companies, once they're split. How you think about what type of debt pay down might be required on the Doc Tech side
componenttext: Ursula, can you just talk a little bit about philosophically anything that has changed how you think about the capital structure of the 2 companies, once they're split. How you think about what type of debt pay down might be required on the Doc Tech side given some of the pressures or just has there been any changes as you've worked through the past few months looking at the split?

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the answer to that in general is no. And I'll answer the question from the combined company perspective, that's the best way to address it and we'll talk about the split companies when we get further in the year. Our ability to generate cash and to hav
componenttext: So the answer to that in general is no. And I'll answer the question from the combined company perspective, that's the best way to address it and we'll talk about the split companies when we get further in the year. Our ability to generate cash and to have it available to operate the business in 2016 is identical, nearly identical to what our ability to generate cash and have it available in 2015. It's really important that we understand that -- let you understand that about $1.6 billion operating cash flow in the year in 2016. We have to spend more on restructuring which we talked about. I think that's a good investment, a very solid investment in '16 and we'll benefit some in 2016 and we'll definitely benefit the 2 companies as we separate. We have separation costs, which are unique and -- in '16, we'll have some in 2017, but a very small amount, a very, very small amount. We have normal CapEx of about $300 million. We have an additional $50 million of CapEx for associated with separation that is also unique in 2016 that give us a cash a balance, a new free cash flow of somewhat [indiscernible] $600 million and $850 million. But most of that $850 million -- the $600 million, the reason why we're there is because of things that we don't expect to repeat in 2017. So as we flow into 2017 or at least 2016, we'll have the a cash ability, generating ability of the 2 new companies that will be circa $1.6 billion just like it is this year without these onetime costs associated with the separation and with the big restructuring that we're taking. So we don't say that we don't view that a lot has changed over the last 4 months that we talked to you at all. We're getting more clear, which we expect to do. We get more clear as we speak to you throughout the year, but it is important that you keep an eye on the fact that fundamental cash flow and fundamental operation of the business has not changed that much.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Shannon.
componenttext: Thanks, Shannon.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Steve Schneiderman with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Steve Schneiderman with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm for Keith Bachman today. So my question is regarding capital allocation. We've noticed that you reduced the M&A target towards the lower end of the previous range. We want to ask, is that more a reflection of market condition, a focus of separation or
componenttext: I'm for Keith Bachman today. So my question is regarding capital allocation. We've noticed that you reduced the M&A target towards the lower end of the previous range. We want to ask, is that more a reflection of market condition, a focus of separation or more of a reduced confidence to get the deal from the pipeline over the hump? And as a follow-on to that, regarding share repurchases, can you talk about a little bit more about the decision to waive the share repurchase for the rest of the year and focus more on the debt reduction or some of the puts and takes there, and why the focus of that regard?

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll start with the share repurchase. I'll take the M&A and Leslie take the share repurchase. Last quarter, we guided that the we would be in the 100 to 400, but at the lower end of the range. What we're doing this quarter is we're narrowing it to th
componenttext: Yes, I'll start with the share repurchase. I'll take the M&A and Leslie take the share repurchase. Last quarter, we guided that the we would be in the 100 to 400, but at the lower end of the range. What we're doing this quarter is we're narrowing it to the end of the range. We don't expect it to be -- for us to be in the $400 million range. So we've actually take that off. Most of it, of the change is driven by the fact that we're doing separation. It's not really a big indication of any significant change in the market. We are pushing hard for the $100 million as I said, between both Doc Tech and Services with a big focus on starting these 2 companies with the right financial position and capital structures. And that's why share repurchase, M&A, debt reduction are all being played against each other to make sure that we have good capital structures. So M&A, $100 million towards the lower end of the range, we're doing there. Share repurchases, Leslie will talk about it. But we've moved share purchase off the table, did $1.3 billion last year, a very, very large amount of share repurchase last year and we don't think we'll do anything this year that will focus on debt reduction.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think Ursula has stolen most of my thunder. As she said, we did do $1.3 billion of share repurchase last year. And we have also increased the dividend, which is the other way that we return capital to our shareholders. With modest M&A this year, we a
componenttext: So I think Ursula has stolen most of my thunder. As she said, we did do $1.3 billion of share repurchase last year. And we have also increased the dividend, which is the other way that we return capital to our shareholders. With modest M&A this year, we are going to prioritize the remaining cash or debt reduction in order to optimize the capital structure of those companies. So we're pretty intense on ensuring that each of the 2 new companies starts competitive, starts lean and starts with an optimized capital structure. And that's where we're focusing our efforts.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve.
componenttext: Thanks, Steve.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of James Friedman of Susquehanna.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of James Friedman of Susquehanna.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to ask about this Slide 9 and contract signings. I didn't hear you mention it in the call. But with regard to the 14% decline in contract signing. I was just wondering, is any of that a function of your deemphasis on Government Healthcare? Lik
componenttext: I just want to ask about this Slide 9 and contract signings. I didn't hear you mention it in the call. But with regard to the 14% decline in contract signing. I was just wondering, is any of that a function of your deemphasis on Government Healthcare? Like is that really an apples to apples number? Or is there something else going on?

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it's actually a lower renewal opportunities in the quarter. So we're really pleased with the renewal rate that we delivered in the quarter of 89%, which is at the high-end of our 85% to 90% target range. But there were less renewal opportunities. We're
componenttext: So it's actually a lower renewal opportunities in the quarter. So we're really pleased with the renewal rate that we delivered in the quarter of 89%, which is at the high-end of our 85% to 90% target range. But there were less renewal opportunities. We're also really pleased that the new business signings in the quarter were up 6% year-over-year. So strong new business, less renewal opportunity, but strong renewal rates.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: We do expect the renewal opportunity for the full year to be essentially the same as it was in 2015. But as you probably know, if you don't know now, that renewals come up in the year at various times. So we expect the full year bucket what it was in 2015
componenttext: We do expect the renewal opportunity for the full year to be essentially the same as it was in 2015. But as you probably know, if you don't know now, that renewals come up in the year at various times. So we expect the full year bucket what it was in 2015, may be a little bit higher.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: That was my follow-up. So that's helpful. Thanks for the clarification.
componenttext: That was my follow-up. So that's helpful. Thanks for the clarification.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jamie.
componenttext: Thanks, Jamie.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes the line of Brian Essex from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes the line of Brian Essex from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if I could touch a little bit on the BPO side of the business, they're up 1% constant currency. Given what you see in the pipeline, particularly the sounding of the toll role contract right now and the New York MIS coming, are there any --
componenttext: I was wondering if I could touch a little bit on the BPO side of the business, they're up 1% constant currency. Given what you see in the pipeline, particularly the sounding of the toll role contract right now and the New York MIS coming, are there any -- I guess, how much visibility do you have into long-term growth? What might you anticipate that growth to be relative to, I think you stated last quarter the BPO industry growing at 5%. And what kind of leverage should we look for as we go throughout the year to achieve those planned marks?

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, so it's Leslie. So I think over the longer term, we are certainly focused on growing at the market. There are clear industries where we participate well like healthcare, like transportation, like customer care where over time, we for sure, should gr
componenttext: Okay, so it's Leslie. So I think over the longer term, we are certainly focused on growing at the market. There are clear industries where we participate well like healthcare, like transportation, like customer care where over time, we for sure, should grow with the market rates. In the near term, we do have some puts and takes associated with some contracts that we have opted out of or contracts that we've lost. So we're pleased with the BPO growth in quarter 1 and believe that for the year, it will enable us BPO combined with Document Outsourcing will enable us to deliver the Services revenue growth that we've commitment, which is flat to up 3%. BPO will be a little bit lumpy in certain quarters depending upon the prior year compare.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Any color in terms of the contracts that you either kind of skipped or opted out of? And what the philosophy is around growing the business going forward? Why -- what were the dynamics of those contracts? And were they -- were they issue with [indiscernib
componenttext: Any color in terms of the contracts that you either kind of skipped or opted out of? And what the philosophy is around growing the business going forward? Why -- what were the dynamics of those contracts? And were they -- were they issue with [indiscernible] or pricing related? Or what might we be able to take away from those?

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so outside the Government Healthcare space where we've made -- and Health Enterprise in particular where we made a very conscious decision to not complete the platforms, in general, if we move out of a contract it's because of the contract profitabil
componenttext: Yes, so outside the Government Healthcare space where we've made -- and Health Enterprise in particular where we made a very conscious decision to not complete the platforms, in general, if we move out of a contract it's because of the contract profitability doesn't meet our thresholds. That's basically -- we don't have a lot of these. This is not a large bucket of business, but we are being very disciplined in assuring that as we move forward with contracts that is particularly, if they are not in the areas of focus for us, which are transportation and healthcare, if they're not in those areas, they have very low profitability and margin profitability, we will move out of those contracts obviously, working with the clients and not leaving them in a lurch.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as we think about the new business that we compete for, we're also being very measured in ensuring that the new business that we take on has the margin profile that we're seeking longer-term for the Services business.
componenttext: And as we think about the new business that we compete for, we're also being very measured in ensuring that the new business that we take on has the margin profile that we're seeking longer-term for the Services business.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brian.
componenttext: Thanks, Brian.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Matt Cabral of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Matt Cabral of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to dig a little bit deeper into the impact of currency, specifically on the yen on Doc Tech margins. If I look at current spot rates on the yen, it looks like it will be up about 9% year-over-year across the remaining 3 quarters relative to the 4%
componenttext: Wanted to dig a little bit deeper into the impact of currency, specifically on the yen on Doc Tech margins. If I look at current spot rates on the yen, it looks like it will be up about 9% year-over-year across the remaining 3 quarters relative to the 4% comparison in Q1. I guess with that in mind, why wouldn't we expect the margin headwinds to get a little bit worse throughout the balance of the year relative to the 100 basis point headwind that you saw in the first quarter?

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Matthew, there's a few things that I think you should understand about the impact of the yen. First of all, we have a currency risk sharing arrangement with Fuji Xerox where they take half, the good news and the bad news, and we take half that happens ove
componenttext: Matthew, there's a few things that I think you should understand about the impact of the yen. First of all, we have a currency risk sharing arrangement with Fuji Xerox where they take half, the good news and the bad news, and we take half that happens over time. Second of all, we do hedge. And therefore, the impact of currency movements will be more muted and will flow in over time. The last point that I would make vis-à-vis the yen strengthening in particular, is that it tends to lead to a less competitive or a more muted competitive pricing environment, a good thing. And we also have the benefit of translating our equity income from Fuji Xerox at more attractive rates when the yen is strong.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then Ursula, as a follow-up. You mentioned in your prepared remarks that you've identified some ways to sharpen the business strategy and improve execution post split. Is there anything that at this point, you can share in those opportunities? And the
componenttext: And then Ursula, as a follow-up. You mentioned in your prepared remarks that you've identified some ways to sharpen the business strategy and improve execution post split. Is there anything that at this point, you can share in those opportunities? And then related to that, how should we think about the go forward strategy for the 2 businesses heading into 2017 after this bit is finalized, relative to how these businesses have been run over the last few years?

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we've had a pretty intense engagement over the last, I think let's say 6 weeks or so that has been refreshing, painful but refreshing in many ways. And for both our Doc Tech businesses, Doc Tech with DO now, and our BPO business, we have found way
componenttext: I think we've had a pretty intense engagement over the last, I think let's say 6 weeks or so that has been refreshing, painful but refreshing in many ways. And for both our Doc Tech businesses, Doc Tech with DO now, and our BPO business, we have found ways to improve 3 major areas. One is how we approach our customers. How we approach them organizationally and in what areas we dive deep with them. And that should help us on the top line, how do we organize that go-to-market in a little bit more efficient way. Second is how do we adjust our cost base inside, particularly we've talked about the spends and layers where we've done a lot of work but with the help of some outside resources, we've been able to look at -- to find ways to be even more sharp there. And then as we separate the 2 companies, we're taking this chance to look at just about every piece of the business that moves and figuring out a way to lean that out those pieces of the businesses that move lean them out and be significantly more efficient. The fundamental strategy so of the Doc Tech business and the BPO business, the fundamental strategies are the same. What we're doing here is we're rounding the edges a bit to make ourselves even more efficient. I was pleased with the work that we've done so far. But we still have some work to do

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. As Ursula said, I think there's 2 primary outcomes. One, is sharpening the strategy for each of the 2 businesses. And then the second is for sure, improving our strategic execution. And part of the strategic execution is the transformation that we've
componenttext: Yes. As Ursula said, I think there's 2 primary outcomes. One, is sharpening the strategy for each of the 2 businesses. And then the second is for sure, improving our strategic execution. And part of the strategic execution is the transformation that we've been talking about.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Matt.
componenttext: Thanks, Matt.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes in the line of Jim Suva from Citigroup.
componenttext: And our next question comes in the line of Jim Suva from Citigroup.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Realizing that the separation has a lot of added costs and a lot of those costs are upfront breakup fees, can you help us understand, are 100% of them or majority of them all going to hit this year? Or do separation costs continue beyond? I'm talking sepa
componenttext: Realizing that the separation has a lot of added costs and a lot of those costs are upfront breakup fees, can you help us understand, are 100% of them or majority of them all going to hit this year? Or do separation costs continue beyond? I'm talking separations, not dyssynergy which I believe are dyssynergy costs are permanent in nature.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the separation costs are dominated by both costs and out flows this year. There will be minimal costs that are incurred and cash outflows that are incurred in 2017.
componenttext: So the separation costs are dominated by both costs and out flows this year. There will be minimal costs that are incurred and cash outflows that are incurred in 2017.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, no. I was just asking if you had more questions. So go ahead, please.
componenttext: No, no. I was just asking if you had more questions. So go ahead, please.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: As a follow-up on the Doc Tech Technology, its clearly it started off a bit softer-than-expected in Q1 but you're kind of your goals for Document Technology for 2016. Is it too additional restructuring that's going to come in and close that gap there? Or
componenttext: As a follow-up on the Doc Tech Technology, its clearly it started off a bit softer-than-expected in Q1 but you're kind of your goals for Document Technology for 2016. Is it too additional restructuring that's going to come in and close that gap there? Or easier comps? Or some visibility to something that you can give us some confidence. Because it looks like the operating margins and just the whole segment overall is starting off a little bit not like where you like to, so how do you kind of close that gap?

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim. Full year, we were careful to be clear about the full year this year because we know that we had -- we have a lot of ups and downs in any given quarter. On a full-year basis, Doc Tech margin, Doc Tech revenue, we are reiterating our guidance
componenttext: Thanks, Jim. Full year, we were careful to be clear about the full year this year because we know that we had -- we have a lot of ups and downs in any given quarter. On a full-year basis, Doc Tech margin, Doc Tech revenue, we are reiterating our guidance and confident that we'll be able to get there. So no debate there. As far as the margins go and the revenue in the first quarter, they were a little bit lighter than we would've expected but not anything that would allow us that would cause us, as I said, to change our guidance. Think about -- if you think about what we did in the second half of last year and actually, in the first quarter so far of this year, the second half of last year we took no restructuring in the Doc Tech business. We did all of our restructuring in the Services segment. So we knew that we would have pressure in margins in the first quarter because we had literally no restructuring to offset the revenue declines. We've doubled up on restructuring in the first quarter. We have even more to do and we've announced the additional $100 million in the second quarter. And we'll top the year at $300 million to restructuring, which is why we are confident that we will be able to actually hit the margin range for the full company that we've talked about, the EPS that we talked about and the adjusted EPS at the talked about. And the revenue shouldn't change that much. So it's the way of the business is slowing, no restructuring second half of the year, big restructuring this year help us to maintain and drive the margin range that we talked about in Doc Tech and in Services and no, we're not moving away from focusing in the market and will be able to actually the revenue guidance that we hit as well.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim. That's all the time we have for questions today. Thanks for your interest. Ursula, anything to wrap up?
componenttext: Thanks, Jim. That's all the time we have for questions today. Thanks for your interest. Ursula, anything to wrap up?

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is, as you can sense from listening to the call, this is a significant year for Xerox. We have 3 fundamental commitments that we have made to our shareholders. To deliver our 2016 guidance. We are on track to do that. We're reiterating our full year
componenttext: This is, as you can sense from listening to the call, this is a significant year for Xerox. We have 3 fundamental commitments that we have made to our shareholders. To deliver our 2016 guidance. We are on track to do that. We're reiterating our full year guidance in EPS and in revenue. We're doing that for both BPO and for Doc Tech and for the full company. Second is to actually implement a strategic transformation that gives us 2 very strong companies, well-seeded companies on January 1 of 2017. And we are well on board, well on past to do that. And we are very confident in our ability to hit the second. The third is to hit the separation date, which is January 1, 2017. A lot of work on that going very well and we're very confident in our ability to do that. So these 3 things we are focused on and we're please with the progress that we're making and very confident in our ability to pull it off. So thank you for joining our call for today and we'll see you next quarter.
