headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Xerox Corporation Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Release Conference Call hosted by Ursula Burns, Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer. She is joined by Leslie Varon, Vice President and Interim Chief Financial Off
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the Xerox Corporation Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Release Conference Call hosted by Ursula Burns, Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer. She is joined by Leslie Varon, Vice President and Interim Chief Financial Officer.
During this call, Xerox executives will refer to slides that are available on the web at www.xerox.com/investor. At the request of Xerox Corporation, today's conference call is being recorded. Other recording and/or rebroadcasting of this call are prohibited without the expressed permission of Xerox. [Operator Instructions]
During this conference call, Xerox executives will make comments that contain forward-looking statements, which, by their nature, address matters that are in the future and are uncertain. Actual future financial results may be materially different than those expressed herein.
At this time, I would like to turn the meeting over to Ms. Burns. Ms. Burns, you may begin.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. Welcome to Xerox's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. At the beginning of the year, we committed to an ambitious agenda that included delivering on our financial goals for 2015 while creating a new path forward that will
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone. Welcome to Xerox's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. At the beginning of the year, we committed to an ambitious agenda that included delivering on our financial goals for 2015 while creating a new path forward that will make our businesses more agile, focused and competitive. I'm pleased to report that we are on track to meet all of these commitments and that we achieved solid financial results this quarter.
Our third quarter EPS was within our guidance range. Cash flow generation was strong and we realized solid margins in both segments despite a challenging global market environment. At the same time, our strategic transformation and separation activities have accelerated significantly. I want to emphasize that these actions are not just about delivering for the quarter or the year. Our strategic transformation program and separation are designed to fundamentally strengthen our businesses and align them closely with the demands of our clients and opportunities in the market. We're embedding productivity and cost efficiency into all areas of our business, which will benefit us for years to come.
We're driving operational excellence and innovation to meet our clients' evolving needs. And we're establishing the new company with talent, business strategies and operating models that will enable them to become more profitable and drive growth over the long term. You will hear much more about these initiatives and the strategies, structures and financial plans of the 2 post separation companies at their investor event in December. But I'm pleased to have the leaders of our new companies, Jeff Jacobson and Ashok Vemuri, here with me today to answer questions about results in their respective businesses during the Q&A.
Before we turn to financial results, let me share some highlights of our progress towards the separation. So with 2 months to go before we complete the separation, we've passed a number of major milestones in the process. The rating agencies released updates on Xerox's credit rating, which will continue to be investment grade, Conduent and corporate is expected to be a high noninvestment-grade-rated company following the separation. These ratings are in line with our expectations.
Upon completion of the spin, Conduent will be listed on the New York Stock Exchange where Xerox will continue to trade. Additionally, we were excited to introduce Conduent's new logo and brand identity. Ashok selected Brian Walsh as the CFO of Conduent. Brian has 20 years of experience in Xerox's finance organization, spanning both operating and corporate roles, and he is currently the CFO of Xerox Services. He is a great fit for the role. And last week, we announced 7 of the 9 directors that will serve on Conduent's board as well as Conduent's named executive officers. With that, the majority of Conduent's leadership team and Board of Directors is in place. We're in the process of filling the remaining 2 board seats, and we'll make those announcements as they become available. 
All of these information about Conduent, along with updated information on its expected capitalization, pro forma financials, compensation plans and governance was included in several amendments to Conduent's Form 10 registration statements.
For Xerox, Jeff is implementing a new more streamlined operating model and has identified the operation's leaders for the stand-alone company, building on our strong, well-established infrastructure and executive team. Jeff continues to focus on filling the remaining executive roles and strengthening the bench, including identifying the right, high-quality individual for the CFO role.
In the interim, Leslie Varon continues to provide strong leadership to our finance organization and will remain in her current role until we have a new CFO in place.
I should point out that beyond senior executive appointments, both Jeff and Ashok have put in place the necessary leadership teams for the major corporate functions. We are now just days away from what we call our soft separation phase. This involves separating our corporate function, business infrastructure and IT systems into discrete capabilities for each company. It's a test run of operating independently for the new companies that will help us ensure a smooth day 1 launch.
In short, we're moving rapidly toward our separation and remain on schedule to complete it by year-end. The benefits of our 3-year strategic transformation program also continued to ramp across both businesses and can clearly be seen in our third quarter performance. We remain on track to deliver $700 million in annualized savings from productivity and cost initiatives this financial year.
With that, I will move to our third quarter results.
As I said, this was a good quarter. We delivered adjusted earnings of $0.27 per share, which was within our guidance range and in line with the same period last year. Total revenue of $4.2 billion showed a 3% decline year-over-year or 4% on an adjusted constant currency basis, which excludes the 2015 charge related to our Health Enterprise strategy change. Operating margin was solid at 9.2%. We saw strong year-over-year margin expansion in our Services segment driven by gains across our BPO businesses, while Document Technology margins remained strong.
Cash flow from operations was $370 million, reflecting a $99 million increase from prior year, and we ended the quarter with a cash balance of $1.4 billion as a result. Overall, our underlying results demonstrated ongoing progress in our productivity and cost savings initiatives and our ability to generate strong cash flow. In addition, we continue to innovate, to deepen our client relationships and extend our capabilities.
Let me highlight a few of our achievements during the quarter.
Starting with our Services segment, which had a number of business wins and high-profile recognitions across the portfolio. We were honored to receive Outstanding Corporate Innovator Award from the Product Development and Management Association for automation, analytics and personalization capabilities. Another notable recognition was by HfS, which named Xerox health care to its winner circle, the highest ranking in its report on business services for health care payers and providers.
In the public sector, the state of Tennessee selected Xerox to provide EMV-enhanced benefit cards to over 120,000 citizens receiving child support, unemployment compensation and state pension payments. Our Document Outsourcing business secured a 10-year contract worth $110 million with the USDA for Managed Print Services. We will be installing and supporting up to 16,000 Xerox ConnectKey-enabled printers and multifunction devices at more than 3,000 USDA locations around the world. Document Outsourcing was also recognized for its market-leading offering by prominent industry analysts groups, including leadership positions in Quocirca's MPS market landscape report and IDC's MarketScape's document workflow services assessment.
Now turning to our Document Technology business. In September, we showcased our portfolio of the latest printing technologies, workflow solutions and business development resources at Graph Expo 2016. This is North America's largest graphic arts trade show. We also brought a number of innovative products for small and midsized businesses to market as we continue to expand our offerings in the space.
At the corporate level, I am proud to share that Xerox released its 2016 global citizenship report, highlighting our approach to social responsibility. Our citizenship efforts continue to be widely recognized. And during the quarter, we were named to the Dow Jones Sustainability World Index, the Dow Jones Sustainability Index for North America and Corporate Responsibility Magazine's 100 Best Corporate Citizens.
I'll now turn it over to Leslie who will provide more detail on our third quarter results and 2016 guidance.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ursula, and good morning, everyone. I'll start with the earnings slide and cover the rest of the financials as well as our guidance before handing it back to Ursula to wrap up.Our third quarter results reflect operational discipline and good pro
componenttext:
Thanks, Ursula, and good morning, everyone. I'll start with the earnings slide and cover the rest of the financials as well as our guidance before handing it back to Ursula to wrap up.
Our third quarter results reflect operational discipline and good progress in key areas that will set the foundation for the 2 companies post-separation. These include cost and productivity progress from our strategic transformation, resulting in broad-based margin improvement in BPO and solid margins in Document Technology; overall services signings growth as we renewed 86% in the quarter with high renewal opportunities, reflecting the continued confidence our customers have in us; strong operating cash generation, reflective of the durability of our annuity-based business model. So while revenues in both businesses were a bit soft, we delivered overall good results in a somewhat volatile macro environment.
Total revenue of $4.2 billion was down 3% at actual currency and down 4% on an adjusted constant currency basis, including 1 point of negative currency. I'll be discussing our results on an adjusted basis when making comparisons against the prior year as the third quarter 2015 included the $389 million pretax charge, including a revenue reduction of $116 million related to our Health Enterprise strategy change.
Adjusted gross margin of 31.3% was up 10 basis points year-over-year, driven by improvements in both segments, partially offset by a greater mix of Services, which structurally has a lower gross margin. There was a modest negative transaction currency impacting quarter 3, reflecting yen strength against the euro, pound and U.S. dollar, partially mitigated by our hedging and currency risk sharing with Fuji Xerox. At current rates, we are expecting some additional pressure in quarter 4.
Adjusted RD&E was down $10 million year-over-year and adjusted SAG was down $28 million, driven by productivity and cost initiatives, which were partially offset by higher expenses related to prior year compensation and benefits reduction. Overall flow-through from our strategic transformation action resulted in good margins in both segments and a solid 9.2% total company operating margin. Adjusted other net expense was down $17 million year-over-year, driven by lower interest expense. Equity income of $39 million in the quarter was down slightly year-over-year.
Our third quarter adjusted tax rate of 25.3% was 1.8 points below last year and just under our guidance range of 26% to 28%, reflecting the geographic mix of our profits. Bottom line, adjusted earnings of $0.27 was in the middle of our guidance range and flat year-over-year.
Turning to Services. We had another quarter of very good operating profit growth, up $33 million or 17% year-over-year, a significant margin improvement, more than offset modest revenue declines. Services revenue was up 1% at actual currency, down 2% at constant currency and adjusting for the prior year Health Enterprise charge. Document Outsourcing grew 1% year-over-year with growth continuing to be driven by Xerox Partner Print Services. 
BPO declined 4% on an adjusted basis, reflecting our continued focus on profitability, very modest inorganic contribution as well as foregone revenue associated with the Health Enterprise strategy change. Within BPO, public sector revenue grew 3% as our transportation business continues to perform well and is benefiting from ramping new business, while commercial industries and health care declined driven by headwinds as we prioritize profitability, and therefore, have stepped away from some unprofitable contracts.
Total signings in the quarter were up 17% year-over-year and are up 6% for the trailing 12 months. The increase in quarter 3 was driven by strong renewal, a reflection of both high renewal opportunity as well as a good renewal rate of 86%, confirming the value we provide our customers. Over the past year, we have renewed 8 of our 10 top BPO clients. New business signings have been lower over the past year as we have strengthened our signings criteria, setting the bar higher on price, margin and deal terms. An important measure of our progress this year is services margin. This has been an area of intense focus, and the team delivered a quarter 3 margin of 9.4%, at the high-end of our 8% to 9.5% full year range. This strong performance reflects broad contribution across BPO, a result of both our strategic cost transformation initiatives and increased operating discipline by the team. And as we've said before, Document Outsourcing margin generally is in line with the Document Technology segment margin.
So key takeaways from Services are consistent with what we said in quarter 2. While revenue was a bit soft, Document Outsourcing remains a good performer; and in BPO, we're making steady progress improving profitability. There's been a near-term trade-off between revenue growth and margin. But overall, it has resulted in strong profit growth and will provide a solid foundation for our businesses as we prepare to separate.
Document Technology delivered strong margins in the face of ongoing revenue pressures within a tough market environment. Revenue was down 9% at actual currency and 7% at constant currency, with equipment down 13% and annuity down 5%. Annuity was an improvement from quarter 2 driven by supplies.
Within equipment, trends improved in both entry and high end, reflecting new product introduction, but mid-range lagged due to lower large account sales in the U.S. When we include Document Outsourcing with Document Technology, revenue declined 5% in the third quarter and is down 4% year-to-date. Overall, we continue to maintain our equipment revenue market share leadership.
Turning to activity. We delivered good growth across all color activity segments with particular strength in high end due in part to the recent drupa trade show. Entry results benefited from better performance in developing markets where we've lapped economic weakness in some geographies. Mid-range had a mixed quarter with continued good growth from the i-Series products launched earlier this year but weakness elsewhere.
Document Technology margin of 13.1% was quite strong, up 50 basis points sequentially, reflecting strategic transformation benefit and within the middle of our full year range. Year-over-year, margin was down 80 basis points as gross margin improvements were not enough to offset a higher SAG ratio. The third quarter 2015 results included materially lower compensation and benefits expense, which we did not expect would repeat. Transaction currency in the quarter was a relatively modest 30 basis point headwind to margin and at current rate could be about twice that level in quarter 4.
So overall for Document Technology, we continued to manage the impact of revenue decline through ongoing productivity actions resulting in strong segment margins and cash generation.
And as I wrap up on the segments, I'll repeat what I said last quarter: we will manage our strategic transformation focus, and we expect continued good profitability in both Document Technology and in services as we prepare to separate.
Moving to cash flow. Operating cash generation of $370 million was strong, up $99 million year-over-year and reflects the underlying cash generative profile of our business model. From a year-over-year perspective, good working capital performance and solid net income more than offset the impact of this year's unique Health Enterprise settlement and separation payment, which were $39 million and $21 million, respectively, in the quarter.
We've generated $522 million of operating cash during the first 3 quarters of the year, with all 2016 Health Enterprise settlement payments now behind us. Therefore, we enter quarter 4, our seasonally strongest cash flow quarter, well positioned to deliver on our guidance of $950 million to $1.2 billion for the full year. Investing cash flows were a use of $69 million and included $73 million spent on CapEx. Cash flow from financing was an $84 million use and includes $85 million for preferred and common stock dividends. Our cash balance at the end of the quarter was $1.4 billion and continues to provide us flexibility as we move into quarter 4 and prepare for separation.
Turning to our capital structure and capital allocation. We ended quarter 3 with $7.4 billion, of debt, a level we've been at all year. Applying 7:1 leverage to our customer financing assets, our allocated financing debt at the end of the quarter was $3.8 billion, leaving core debt at $3.6 billion. We continue to manage our capital structure to maintain credit metrics consistent with our investment-grade credit rating. On October 11, we filed an amendment to the Conduent Form 10 that included details of its anticipated post-separation capital structure. We indicated that Conduent expected to be capitalized with approximately $2.4 billion of debt and $400 million of cash and to transfer $2.05 billion of proceeds to Xerox, which we intend to use to reduce Xerox debt.
Consistent with our expectation, Xerox credit ratings remain investment grade, and we expect that the Conduent capital structure would result in a high noninvestment-grade rating.
And to touch on capital allocation. We've paid $79 million in common stock dividends in quarter 3. We completed a $13 million dealer acquisition earlier this month, consistent with our strategy to expand our U.S. Global Imaging business. And as we've said previously, as we prepare for our separation later this year, we're not planning to repurchase any shares.
Before I move to guidance on the next slide, I want to mention that Conduent will be filing its third quarter results in the next few weeks. The Conduent carve-out financials will reflect margin improvement, although not to the same degree as the Services segment since Conduent results include the student loan business, which resides in our Other segment. That business is in runoff and decline profit year-over-year as anticipated.
I'll now share with you our fourth quarter and full year expectations. For quarter 4, we expect adjusted earnings in the range of $0.32 to $0.35 and GAAP earnings of $0.11 to $0.14. For the full year, we continue to expect total revenues to decline 2% to 4% at constant currency. We're narrowing our adjusted earnings guidance range to $1.11 to $1.14, which incorporates our fourth quarter expectation.
In Services, we expect full year revenue will be flat to down 1% and margin will be at the very high end of the 8% to 9.5% range. We expect Document Technology revenues will be at the lower end of the full year range and that margin will be in line with our 12% to 14% expectation.
We expect full year GAAP earnings of $0.45 to $0.48. We continue to anticipate full year restructuring of about $300 million, including approximately $70 million in the fourth quarter and our estimate of pretax separation costs remains $175 million to $200 million and $40 million to $50 million in tax-related friction costs.
Turning to cash flow. As I mentioned earlier, our year-to-date performance positions us well for the full year and we are maintaining our expectations of $950 million to $1.2 billion for operating cash flow and $600 million to $850 million for free cash flow.
And finally, our capital allocation expectations remain largely unchanged, although we now expect to spend about $30 million to $50 million on acquisition.
So in summary, despite a somewhat challenging macro backdrop, we are on track and remain committed to delivering our overall revenue, earnings and cash flow guidance.
With that, Ursula, I'll turn it back to you.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Leslie. In summary, we are pleased with our results in the third quarter, which were in line with our expectation and driven by our ongoing operational and cost discipline. We are on track to deliver on all of our objectives for the year and es
componenttext:
Thank you, Leslie. In summary, we are pleased with our results in the third quarter, which were in line with our expectation and driven by our ongoing operational and cost discipline. We are on track to deliver on all of our objectives for the year and establish 2 companies that will be well positioned to drive shareholder value over the long term.
Before we open the line for questions, I would like to note that today has particular significance for Xerox, as this will be our last earnings call as a combined entity. Next time we report earnings, we will be 2 separate companies, each on their own path to enhance value for our clients, employees, investors and other stakeholders.
I look forward to watching both Xerox and Conduent prosper in the future.
We will now open up the line for questions. Jennifer?

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ursula. Joining us today are Jeff Jacobson, head of our Document Technology business and CEO of new Xerox following separation; Ashok Vemuri, Chief Executive Officer, Xerox Business Services and CEO of Conduent post-separation; and Brian Webb-Wals
componenttext:
Thanks, Ursula. Joining us today are Jeff Jacobson, head of our Document Technology business and CEO of new Xerox following separation; Ashok Vemuri, Chief Executive Officer, Xerox Business Services and CEO of Conduent post-separation; and Brian Webb-Walsh, CFO, Xerox Services who will be CFO of Conduent post-separation. 
Before we get to your questions, let me point out that we have several supplemental slides at the end of our deck, which provide more financial details to support today's presentation and complement our prepared remarks. [Operator Instructions] At the end of our Q&A session, I will turn it back to Ursula for closing comments.
Operator, please open the line for questions now.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of George Tong from Piper Jaffray.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ashok, first of all, welcome to Xerox. Understanding more details will be provided at the upcoming Analyst Day. Ashok, can you provide or touch on what your top 3 strategic priorities are to improve growth and margin performance in the BPO business?
componenttext: Ashok, first of all, welcome to Xerox. Understanding more details will be provided at the upcoming Analyst Day. Ashok, can you provide or touch on what your top 3 strategic priorities are to improve growth and margin performance in the BPO business?

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Sure, George. I think the focus for us continues to be to drive profitable growth. We have demonstrated a very strong margin performance. We continue to invest in the strategic transformation to turn the business, so that we are invested and investin
componenttext: Yes. Sure, George. I think the focus for us continues to be to drive profitable growth. We have demonstrated a very strong margin performance. We continue to invest in the strategic transformation to turn the business, so that we are invested and investing in areas that are our traditional strength. We have certain areas where we would like to continue to drive a higher degree of transformation, especially customer care. But we're pleased with the progress that we have made on the margin front, and I think that will give us the momentum to be able to continue to drive the transformation that we seek in our business.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very helpful. And the earnings release this quarter disclosed that work to implement the Health Enterprise platform in New York has been elongated and could result in material increases and future costs to complete. Can you help frame or quantify the pote
componenttext: Very helpful. And the earnings release this quarter disclosed that work to implement the Health Enterprise platform in New York has been elongated and could result in material increases and future costs to complete. Can you help frame or quantify the potential cost overruns and comment on your desire to remain in the government health care business given some of the recent difficulties in ramping contracts in the segment?

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we are working in a very collaborative fashion with the state. The good news is that we have learned sort of our lessons and have gained some experience based on our prior implementations. We're working closely with the state. We are making progre
componenttext: Yes. So we are working in a very collaborative fashion with the state. The good news is that we have learned sort of our lessons and have gained some experience based on our prior implementations. We're working closely with the state. We are making progress on the implementation. And given that these contracts and implementations are usually long tenor and have changing requirements and ups and downs, I think we are, given all of that, making very decent progress.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Shannon Cross from Cross Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Shannon Cross from Cross Research.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have 2 questions. The first is for Jeff. Just how do we think about what's going on in the underlying business in the printing business. I mean, equipment was down 13% in Doc Tech. I think combined, it was -- I don't know what equipment was down. But ov
componenttext: I have 2 questions. The first is for Jeff. Just how do we think about what's going on in the underlying business in the printing business. I mean, equipment was down 13% in Doc Tech. I think combined, it was -- I don't know what equipment was down. But overall, the sort of printing business was down about 5% constant currency when you add in Document Outsourcing. So I'm just curious, just sort of how you see the competitive landscape. The yen has obviously moved significantly. Your competitors in Japan are not reporting particularly good numbers. So what are you seeing out there as you sort of head into '17? And then I have a question for Ashok.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Shannon. Thanks very much. So first, let me address it from a global market and macro standpoint. So the global market environment continues to be challenging. As you mentioned, Shannon, there are uncertainties with currencies fluctuating in the yen
componenttext: Sure, Shannon. Thanks very much. So first, let me address it from a global market and macro standpoint. So the global market environment continues to be challenging. As you mentioned, Shannon, there are uncertainties with currencies fluctuating in the yen and the pound. Certainly, these -- the uncertainty of the presidential election in the U.S., the Brexit adds a certain degree of uncertainty in the U.K. and Europe. But these complexities are obviously what we deal with all the time. And the important thing are the counter measures. So what we're doing is we're very aggressive on the productivity measures to drive down our total delivered costs and enhance the operating margins. As you know, what we've done over the last couple of years have been pretty aggressive on productivity, and we're taking that to the next level. We're very focused on innovation and defending our market share. And we're focused on the growth areas. So specific to this quarter, what I'd say, our revenue was in line and was stable in this challenging market environment. You're correct that we were pressured on the equipment side, and some of that was more in the high end and government bids due to these uncertainties. But we're also pleased with the annuity business driven by supplies, and we're also pleased on the high end. We saw the impact of drupa, which will benefit us for the next couple of quarters. And then at the end of September, we obviously had Graph Expo in the U.S. and we think that will benefit us. So overall, in line, good color installs and pressure more on the mono side as we're moving more sort of color in the macro environment.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then, Ashok, can you talk a bit about how you think about the balance between revenue and margin? Because over the last 3 years, Xerox has sort of bounced between wanting a lot of revenue growth out of BPO but then that's obviously impact to ma
componenttext: Great. And then, Ashok, can you talk a bit about how you think about the balance between revenue and margin? Because over the last 3 years, Xerox has sort of bounced between wanting a lot of revenue growth out of BPO but then that's obviously impact to margin depending on what you signed versus sometimes saying, no, we're going to focus more on margin, and therefore, we saw revenue decline and impact to billings -- or bookings. So just sort of philosophically, how do you think about -- I know it's a balancing act. But where do you put more weight to?

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Shannon, my philosophy on this is we need profitable growth. Revenue growth is important in order to demonstrate that the investments are in the right place and we are continuing to provide value to our clients. Margin is an indicator of 2 things for m
componenttext: So Shannon, my philosophy on this is we need profitable growth. Revenue growth is important in order to demonstrate that the investments are in the right place and we are continuing to provide value to our clients. Margin is an indicator of 2 things for me. One is the value that our clients perceive that we are bringing to the table and are willing to pay for it. And secondly, it's a report card on our -- on management's ability to effectively and efficiently run a business. So both of these are important for the reasons I just described. And I think even though there's a certain degree of elasticity between them, it is important to manage that elasticity in a way that we see growth on both fronts.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Tien-tsin Huang from JPMorgan Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Tien-tsin Huang from JPMorgan Securities.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to dig in here just on the revenue coming in somewhat soft. I know the profitability came in nicely. But just how much of the -- you think is macro versus your profitability focus versus maybe, I guess, distractions from the split or the spin.
componenttext: Just wanted to dig in here just on the revenue coming in somewhat soft. I know the profitability came in nicely. But just how much of the -- you think is macro versus your profitability focus versus maybe, I guess, distractions from the split or the spin. Can you maybe rank those?

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll start on the services side with Ashok and then switch a little bit to the tech side with Jeff.
componenttext: We'll start on the services side with Ashok and then switch a little bit to the tech side with Jeff.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So I think what we have seen in terms of the margin improvement is clearly the flow-through of all the strategic transformation activities that we've been doing. There's a higher degree of discipline that we have driven. We have balanced some of the
componenttext: Okay. So I think what we have seen in terms of the margin improvement is clearly the flow-through of all the strategic transformation activities that we've been doing. There's a higher degree of discipline that we have driven. We have balanced some of the revenue reduction because we are being much more selective in terms of the deals we are doing. Deal qualification has improved. The bars that we have put in terms of pricing and the kind of deals that we want to do, we've raised that. So margins, as I've said, in answer to the previous question, is extremely important for us. So we need to balance that by also driving revenue growth.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I think from the tech standpoint, when you see the equipment revenue, that would tend to be impacted more by uncertainties and the macro issues. We're very fortunate from the standpoint that 75% of our business is annuity, which provides a strong
componenttext: Yes. And I think from the tech standpoint, when you see the equipment revenue, that would tend to be impacted more by uncertainties and the macro issues. We're very fortunate from the standpoint that 75% of our business is annuity, which provides a strong foundation, strong base. We're also very fortunate that the vast majority of our contracts are bundled contracts with suppliers, which provides stability for us. So what we're doing is we're not getting out ahead of our headlights. We're managing our cost and productivity very strongly, and we're looking for the opportunities to grow certainly in Document Outsourcing, Graphic Communications and in some underpenetrated markets for us such as SMB.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ananda Baruah from Brean Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ananda Baruah from Brean Capital.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Really, my question right now, I have one. It's really for Jeff and maybe for Ursula on the Xerox side. As we think about where the opportunities for incremental efficiencies could be as you get post-split and then as we think about where the opportunitie
componenttext: Really, my question right now, I have one. It's really for Jeff and maybe for Ursula on the Xerox side. As we think about where the opportunities for incremental efficiencies could be as you get post-split and then as we think about where the opportunities for, I guess, increased velocity around decision-making could be post-split, how should we be thinking about it? What things have you guys learned about those opportunities so far? And understanding, you probably don't have numbers to give us yet. I guess, from a magnitude perspective -- I, guess from -- what context in terms of -- like how should we think about it in terms of potential to be impactful on the P&L? Like what's the right context there as well? And that's it, would love your thoughts there.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So sure, Ananda. Thanks very much. And certainly, we'll cover a lot more of the details at the investor conference. But the way we look at it is this, if you look at the strategic transformation we announced over a 3-year period as a combined entity,
componenttext: Yes. So sure, Ananda. Thanks very much. And certainly, we'll cover a lot more of the details at the investor conference. But the way we look at it is this, if you look at the strategic transformation we announced over a 3-year period as a combined entity, about $2.4 billion, and we said that tech would be about 2/3 of that. So we -- the linchpin to our strategy is driving that strategic transformation very hard. And the reason is this: In past years, basically, we've offset the headwinds of annuity, price erosion and done just enough. What we want to do now is take this to a totally another level, so that we can reinvest back in the business, bring some back down to the bottom line and invest in some of the growth areas we see, certainly, in Document Outsourcing, Graphic Communications and being able to invest a little more into entry. And we'll talk a little bit more about that at Investor Day. In terms of the strategic transformation, we're driving it very hard. We're looking at things such as supply chain optimization, technical service excellence with remote call assist, remote connectivity, real estate optimization, how we can design our products with more efficiency and then delayering and simplifying the organization. So we have a pretty detailed plan, we're tracking very well towards it, and we're pleased with where we are right now.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I have -- that's really helpful, Jeff. I got a quick follow-up to that, if I could. Are those moves -- the nonrevenue moves, the core organizational moves you talked to, are those incremental to business-as-usual Xerox? And if they're incremental to b
componenttext: And I have -- that's really helpful, Jeff. I got a quick follow-up to that, if I could. Are those moves -- the nonrevenue moves, the core organizational moves you talked to, are those incremental to business-as-usual Xerox? And if they're incremental to business-as-usual Xerox, would you favor the incremental op profit dollars to be dropped to the bottom line or invest it back into growth or both of those things?

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So one of the things in our message is that there's no business as usual at Xerox. So what we're going to do as we separate our companies is we're going to take all the good things that we bring from Xerox, there are a lot of great things, but we're going
componenttext: So one of the things in our message is that there's no business as usual at Xerox. So what we're going to do as we separate our companies is we're going to take all the good things that we bring from Xerox, there are a lot of great things, but we're going to be a much more simplified, delayered organization. And what we're going to do with the efficiencies we drive in taking strategic transformation to the next level, some will certainly drop to the bottom line and some of it will be invested to improve the revenue trajectory.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Essex from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Essex from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ashok, I was wondering if I could maybe ask you about the services performance. And now that you've been there for a little while and you've rolled up your sleeves, how much of the lower guidance is due to the more -- the greater degree of selectivity in
componenttext: Ashok, I was wondering if I could maybe ask you about the services performance. And now that you've been there for a little while and you've rolled up your sleeves, how much of the lower guidance is due to the more -- the greater degree of selectivity in contracts? And I know that the margins are now kind of pointed towards the high end. How much of the margin is due to your strategic transformation versus pricing?

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the margin improvement, Brian, are to a great extent driven by the efficiency that we have seen. And remember that this margin improvement that we have seen comes despite our performance in customer care, and I'll elaborate more on that as w
componenttext: Well, I think the margin improvement, Brian, are to a great extent driven by the efficiency that we have seen. And remember that this margin improvement that we have seen comes despite our performance in customer care, and I'll elaborate more on that as we go into [indiscernible], et cetera. But clearly the -- where our business is actually clicking in and the ones that we are investing and amplifying, these are coming in at decent margins and actually much improved margins than previous period. But we still have ways to go in terms of being able to transform some of our businesses, which are core to us. And as we do that, as we get more selective, as we drive a much more predictable and sustainable, scalable business and we have the foundation for it, I think we would be able to see the performance of that in future quarters.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And maybe as a follow-up, in terms of transforming the business again, as I think back to conversations that we previously have with Bob for example, we've talked about centralizing the legacy -- relatively distributed nature of the legacy ACS busin
componenttext: Okay. And maybe as a follow-up, in terms of transforming the business again, as I think back to conversations that we previously have with Bob for example, we've talked about centralizing the legacy -- relatively distributed nature of the legacy ACS business. I mean, how far along from previous initiatives are we? And then how much more room is there to go within that organization in terms of increasing its efficiency? Maybe if we can get a -- if we can just get a sense of your fresh take on the business and what's new in the way that you view it.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the good news is that this is not something that we've just decided or contemplated to do. This is in progress. So we've taken enough initiatives and more, if you will, on transforming the business. In some places, we've been effective. We clearly
componenttext: Yes. So the good news is that this is not something that we've just decided or contemplated to do. This is in progress. So we've taken enough initiatives and more, if you will, on transforming the business. In some places, we've been effective. We clearly have a business which is very widespread both from the range of businesses that we do, the range of clients that we have and the geographical spread. So we need to refocus ourselves on those things that we are really good at, amplify those and invest in them and continue to drive -- through the strategic transformation initiative, drive this to success. But I think the important thing is to also understand that this is not something that's going to happen overnight or in a few quarters. This is a transformation. It is going to transition over a period of time. And we will discuss the appropriate metric as we bridge from where we are to where we really want to be.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Frank Atkins from SunTrust.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Frank Atkins from SunTrust.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to ask, Ashok, what are the major levers that you see to pull to drive profitability going forward?
componenttext: I want to ask, Ashok, what are the major levers that you see to pull to drive profitability going forward?

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the number one, of course, is we have to refocus on our delivery model. Customer care is a big part of what we do. Innovation in that, either through robotics and automation, is a key part of what we do. There are some internal processes in
componenttext: Well, I think the number one, of course, is we have to refocus on our delivery model. Customer care is a big part of what we do. Innovation in that, either through robotics and automation, is a key part of what we do. There are some internal processes in how we run ourselves, which we could use some of those similar processes and tools to make us much more effective and efficient. We have to look for businesses that will provide us profitable growth. We have to exploit it and monetize all the assets that we have within the company. And we have a ton of them which we need to be deployed across the board. We have to look at businesses and segments and geographies which will help us meet those profitability goals. And in certain situations, we also have to sort of run off businesses that we're deliberately taking a view on running off.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Matt Cabral from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Matt Cabral from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask about the proposed Conduent balance sheet. I guess, on my estimates, it looks like the business will start off with north of 3x gross leverage, which seemed a little bit high relative to where some of the pure-play BPO competitors are, and
componenttext: I wanted to ask about the proposed Conduent balance sheet. I guess, on my estimates, it looks like the business will start off with north of 3x gross leverage, which seemed a little bit high relative to where some of the pure-play BPO competitors are, and given the meaningful turnaround that this business faces going forward. So I guess, what gives you the confidence that this is the right capital structure for Conduent going forward? And does this level of leverage still give you room to make either the organic or inorganic investments needed to transform this business ahead?

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Matt, it's Brian. As Ursula and Leslie both mentioned, we anticipate being a high noninvestment-grade-rated company. We believe the leverage that we're starting with is manageable. We intend to improve the leverage over time through operational perform
componenttext: So Matt, it's Brian. As Ursula and Leslie both mentioned, we anticipate being a high noninvestment-grade-rated company. We believe the leverage that we're starting with is manageable. We intend to improve the leverage over time through operational performance improvement. So again, we will use cost transformation to create room to make organic investments. The inorganic investments will be timed as we can afford them, but we believe that it's a manageable starting point.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm just going to ask one for Jeff, more on the legacy Xerox business. I guess, I wanted to ask around the USDA contract win that was mentioned in the prepared remarks. And first of all, is there any help around the ramp of that contract? And then more ju
componenttext: I'm just going to ask one for Jeff, more on the legacy Xerox business. I guess, I wanted to ask around the USDA contract win that was mentioned in the prepared remarks. And first of all, is there any help around the ramp of that contract? And then more just taking a step back and looking at that vertical in particular, around U.S. federal, was that a sort of opportunistic one-off win? Or is that an area where there might be a little bit more of a robust pipeline, particularly given the pending Lexmark acquisition that's out there?

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Matt. Not specific to the Lexmark acquisition, but I think more of the USDA win, we're very strong in federal, we're very strong in public sector. Document Outsourcing is a strong and really good business for us. We're the clear market leader
componenttext: Yes. Thanks, Matt. Not specific to the Lexmark acquisition, but I think more of the USDA win, we're very strong in federal, we're very strong in public sector. Document Outsourcing is a strong and really good business for us. We're the clear market leader, and we continue to see growth and strong margins in that business. It's an area of focus, strategic importance to us. And we had a good renewal rate. We continue -- we're very strong in the large enterprise sector. We're always focused on new logos and new customers, and this was a big part of that. In addition to that, we're going to apply that same expertise, if I can call it that, to the Managed Print Services in the SMB sector as well, where we even have a lot more opportunity for growth there.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Keith Bachman from BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Keith Bachman from BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Steve Schneiderman sitting for Keith today. I wanted to direct this to Ashok. As we think about getting an update on the sales cycle, signings for the quarter were up about 15%. I understand this includes Document Outsourcing. But signings are dow
componenttext: This is Steve Schneiderman sitting for Keith today. I wanted to direct this to Ashok. As we think about getting an update on the sales cycle, signings for the quarter were up about 15%. I understand this includes Document Outsourcing. But signings are down by about the same amount, as you talked about trying to be more selective on profitable growth. My question is, where are we in this cycle in terms of churning out these low-profit potential new deals and being able to once again being able to look at a more steady state of signings growth?

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So from our signings growth perspective, it grew about 17%, and the bulk of that actually came from renewals. So that is actually good news. We have 8 out of our 10 BPO clients actually renewed with us. So obviously, whatever we're bringing to the pa
componenttext: Yes. So from our signings growth perspective, it grew about 17%, and the bulk of that actually came from renewals. So that is actually good news. We have 8 out of our 10 BPO clients actually renewed with us. So obviously, whatever we're bringing to the party, our clients like and they can -- they want to continue to do business with us. The area of concern, if you will, for us is new deal signings. That is down. And that is an area of focus. I call in my go-to-market team in October. We basically sat down to look at the opportunities in the market. In the spaces that we are strong in, there continues to be headroom for growth and there are opportunities out there, which we will selectively take to drive profitable growth.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Is this something, you think, can be resolved mid-2017? Or is that about a little conservative or aggressive from that perspective?
componenttext: Okay. Is this something, you think, can be resolved mid-2017? Or is that about a little conservative or aggressive from that perspective?

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's difficult to put a time line on this. But suffice it to say that we are intensely focused on driving revenue, in driving new business growth while at the same time continuing to respond to the trust our existing clients have placed in us by b
componenttext: I think it's difficult to put a time line on this. But suffice it to say that we are intensely focused on driving revenue, in driving new business growth while at the same time continuing to respond to the trust our existing clients have placed in us by bringing innovative solutions to the table.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jim Suva from Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jim Suva from Citigroup.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have 2 questions, and I'll ask them both at the same time. First of all, as you prepare for separation, and I'm sure the ERP, your internal IT systems you have are preparing for -- there's a lot of effort ahead of that. Are you going to have a need to,
componenttext: I have 2 questions, and I'll ask them both at the same time. First of all, as you prepare for separation, and I'm sure the ERP, your internal IT systems you have are preparing for -- there's a lot of effort ahead of that. Are you going to have a need to, say, meaningfully increase your inventory just to make sure that one system doesn't actually not talk to another system? Or is that inventory management have already ironed out? And then my second question is, on the Affordable Care Act and the election, there's been a lot of talk about that as well as costs going up on that. Can you help us quantify what that means to Xerox? Or do we know -- or with cost going up, is that bad, is that good in enrollees or is there no impact at all? Or how should we think about the election and the Affordable Care Act of what's going on the news?

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Jim, I should take that. This is Ursula. I haven't spoken a lot today. It's actually a good feeling. But I'll take that question. First one, on the transition and inventory and how we're looking at that. We're entering something, I talked about this in
componenttext: So Jim, I should take that. This is Ursula. I haven't spoken a lot today. It's actually a good feeling. But I'll take that question. First one, on the transition and inventory and how we're looking at that. We're entering something, I talked about this in my prepared remarks, a phase that we call soft separation. And the reason why that's important for investors is that it's a time that we can essentially practice, do a phased implementation of all of the complex separation activities and make sure that we don't stumble on -- when we're actually independent, including things like the inventory management system. Independent of the soft separation, we would have very little problem with this area. But I think the soft separation makes it such that we can actually double and triple check there. So I wouldn't -- we don't -- we're not managing inventory any differently than we normally would at the end of the year. All we're doing is making sure that as we do a separation, we don't have any fumbles, which we don't expect. As far as costs and the impact -- health care costs, the impact of ACA or any potential changes to ACA on our internal cost and the marketplace, we actually just don't see any. Internal costs, we will manage our internal health care costs in the most efficient way possible. I mean, we are a good health care provider, payer of services for our clients. Our customers haven't changed. And as far as the marketplace out there, we're not really seeing a big set of headwinds or change in the market dynamics because of any potential changes for ACA. I hope I answered both of your questions.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our last question for the day is coming from the line of Jamie Friedman from Susquehanna.
componenttext: Our last question for the day is coming from the line of Jamie Friedman from Susquehanna.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just had a housekeeping question. Leslie, maybe if you could share with us what the time frame is from here. So I know you filed a Form 10 and an amended Form 10. Is there another Form 10 coming? Maybe if you could just update us on the sequence as we g
componenttext: I just had a housekeeping question. Leslie, maybe if you could share with us what the time frame is from here. So I know you filed a Form 10 and an amended Form 10. Is there another Form 10 coming? Maybe if you could just update us on the sequence as we go out?

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Brian. There will be an amendment to the Form 10 today, actually. And then we anticipate the Form 10 being effective in early November.
componenttext: Yes, this is Brian. There will be an amendment to the Form 10 today, actually. And then we anticipate the Form 10 being effective in early November.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. What is the anticipated date of separation?
componenttext: Okay. What is the anticipated date of separation?

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: End of the year is the anticipated date of separation.
componenttext: End of the year is the anticipated date of separation.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: As it has been from the time that we started.
componenttext: As it has been from the time that we started.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm going to pass it back to Ursula for some closing comments.
componenttext: I'm going to pass it back to Ursula for some closing comments.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So thank you for your questions. In the third quarter, we made steady progress against all 3 of our commitments: delivering on our 2016 financial goals, implementing our strategic transformation and completing the separation by year-end. We remain on trac
componenttext: So thank you for your questions. In the third quarter, we made steady progress against all 3 of our commitments: delivering on our 2016 financial goals, implementing our strategic transformation and completing the separation by year-end. We remain on track to achieve all 3. We look forward to sharing more details about the 2 companies at our Investor Days, and thank you, everyone, for joining the call.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ursula. That concludes our call today. If you have further questions, please contact me or any member of our Investor Relations team.
componenttext: Thanks, Ursula. That concludes our call today. If you have further questions, please contact me or any member of our Investor Relations team.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you again for your participation. You may now disconnect at this time. Everyone, have a great day.
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you again for your participation. You may now disconnect at this time. Everyone, have a great day.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Xerox Corporation Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Release Conference Call hosted by Ursula Burns, Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer. She is joined by Leslie Varon, Vice President and Interim Chief Financial Off
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the Xerox Corporation Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Release Conference Call hosted by Ursula Burns, Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer. She is joined by Leslie Varon, Vice President and Interim Chief Financial Officer.
During this call, Xerox executives will refer to slides that are available on the web at www.xerox.com/investor. At the request of Xerox Corporation, today's conference call is being recorded. Other recording and/or rebroadcasting of this call are prohibited without the expressed permission of Xerox. [Operator Instructions]
During this conference call, Xerox executives will make comments that contain forward-looking statements, which, by their nature, address matters that are in the future and are uncertain. Actual future financial results may be materially different than those expressed herein.
At this time, I would like to turn the meeting over to Ms. Burns. Ms. Burns, you may begin.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. Welcome to Xerox's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. At the beginning of the year, we committed to an ambitious agenda that included delivering on our financial goals for 2015 while creating a new path forward that will
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone. Welcome to Xerox's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. At the beginning of the year, we committed to an ambitious agenda that included delivering on our financial goals for 2015 while creating a new path forward that will make our businesses more agile, focused and competitive. I'm pleased to report that we are on track to meet all of these commitments and that we achieved solid financial results this quarter.
Our third quarter EPS was within our guidance range. Cash flow generation was strong and we realized solid margins in both segments despite a challenging global market environment. At the same time, our strategic transformation and separation activities have accelerated significantly. I want to emphasize that these actions are not just about delivering for the quarter or the year. Our strategic transformation program and separation are designed to fundamentally strengthen our businesses and align them closely with the demands of our clients and opportunities in the market. We're embedding productivity and cost efficiency into all areas of our business, which will benefit us for years to come.
We're driving operational excellence and innovation to meet our clients' evolving needs. And we're establishing the new company with talent, business strategies and operating models that will enable them to become more profitable and drive growth over the long term. You will hear much more about these initiatives and the strategies, structures and financial plans of the 2 post-separation companies at their investor event in December. But I'm pleased to have the leaders of our new companies, Jeff Jacobson and Ashok Vemuri, here with me today to answer questions about results in their respective businesses during the Q&A.
Before we turn to financial results, let me share some highlights of our progress towards the separation. So with 2 months to go before we complete the separation, we've passed a number of major milestones in the process. The rating agencies released updates on Xerox's credit rating, which will continue to be investment grade, Conduent Inc. is expected to be a high noninvestment-grade-rated company following the separation. These ratings are in line with our expectations.
Upon completion of the spin, Conduent will be listed on the New York Stock Exchange where Xerox will continue to trade. Additionally, we were excited to introduce Conduent's new logo and brand identity. Ashok selected Brian Walsh as the CFO of Conduent. Brian has 20 years of experience in Xerox's finance organization, spanning both operating and corporate roles, and he is currently the CFO of Xerox Services. He is a great fit for the role. And last week, we announced 7 of the 9 directors that will serve on Conduent's board as well as Conduent's named executive officers. With that, the majority of Conduent's leadership team and Board of Directors is in place. We're in the process of filling the remaining 2 board seats, and we'll make those announcements as they become available. 
All of this information about Conduent, along with updated information on its expected capitalization, pro forma financials, compensation plans and governance was included in several amendments to Conduent's Form 10 registration statements.
For Xerox, Jeff is implementing a new, more streamlined operating model and has identified the operation's leaders for the stand-alone company, building on our strong, well-established infrastructure and executive team. Jeff continues to focus on filling the remaining executive roles and strengthening the bench, including identifying the right, high-quality individual for the CFO role.
In the interim, Leslie Varon continues to provide strong leadership to our finance organization and will remain in her current role until we have a new CFO in place.
I should point out that beyond senior executive appointments, both Jeff and Ashok have put in place the necessary leadership teams for the major corporate functions. We are now just days away from what we call our soft separation phase. This involves separating our corporate function, business infrastructure and IT systems into discrete capabilities for each company. It's a test run at operating independently for the new companies that will help us ensure a smooth day one launch.
In short, we're moving rapidly toward our separation and remain on schedule to complete it by year-end. The benefits of our 3-year strategic transformation program also continued to ramp across both businesses and can clearly be seen in our third quarter performance. We remain on track to deliver $700 million in annualized savings from productivity and cost initiatives this financial year.
With that, I will move to our third quarter results.
As I said, this was a good quarter. We delivered adjusted earnings of $0.27 per share, which was within our guidance range and in line with the same period last year. Total revenue of $4.2 billion showed a 3% decline year-over-year or 4% on an adjusted constant currency basis, which excludes the 2015 charge related to our Health Enterprise strategy change. Operating margin was solid at 9.2%. We saw strong year-over-year margin expansion in our Services segment driven by gains across our BPO businesses, while Document Technology margins remained strong.
Cash flow from operations was $370 million, reflecting a $99 million increase from prior year, and we ended the quarter with a cash balance of $1.4 billion as a result. Overall, our underlying results demonstrated ongoing progress in our productivity and cost savings initiatives and our ability to generate strong cash flow. In addition, we continue to innovate, to deepen our client relationships and extend our capabilities.
Let me highlight a few of our achievements during the quarter.
Starting with our Services segment, which had a number of business wins and high-profile recognitions across the portfolio. We were honored to receive Outstanding Corporate Innovator Award from the Product Development and Management Association for automation, analytics and personalization capabilities. Another notable recognition was by HfS, which named Xerox health care to its winner circle, the highest ranking in its report on business services for health care payers and providers.
In the public sector, the state of Tennessee selected Xerox to provide EMV-enhanced benefit cards to over 120,000 citizens receiving child support, unemployment compensation and state pension payments. Our Document Outsourcing business secured a 10-year contract worth $110 million with the USDA for Managed Print Services. We will be installing and supporting up to 16,000 Xerox ConnectKey-enabled printers and multifunction devices at more than 3,000 USDA locations around the world. Document Outsourcing was also recognized for its market-leading offering by prominent industry analysts groups, including leadership positions in Quocirca's MPS market landscape report and IDC's MarketScape's document workflow services assessment.
Now turning to our Document Technology business. In September, we showcased our portfolio of the latest printing technologies, workflow solutions and business development resources at Graph Expo 2016. This is North America's largest graphic arts trade show. We also brought a number of innovative products for small and midsized businesses to market as we continue to expand our offerings in this space.
At the corporate level, I am proud to share that Xerox released its 2016 global citizenship report, highlighting our approach to social responsibility. Our citizenship efforts continue to be widely recognized. And during the quarter, we were named to the Dow Jones Sustainability World Index, the Dow Jones Sustainability Index for North America and Corporate Responsibility Magazine's 100 Best Corporate Citizens.
I'll now turn it over to Leslie who will provide more detail on our third quarter results and 2016 guidance.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ursula, and good morning, everyone. I'll start with the earnings slide and cover the rest of the financials as well as our guidance before handing it back to Ursula to wrap up.Our third quarter results reflect operational discipline and good pro
componenttext:
Thanks, Ursula, and good morning, everyone. I'll start with the earnings slide and cover the rest of the financials as well as our guidance before handing it back to Ursula to wrap up.
Our third quarter results reflect operational discipline and good progress in key areas that will set the foundation for the 2 companies post-separation. These include cost and productivity progress from our strategic transformation, resulting in broad-based margin improvement in BPO and solid margins in Document Technology; overall services signings growth as we renewed 86% in the quarter with high renewal opportunities, reflecting the continued confidence our customers have in us; strong operating cash generation, reflective of the durability of our annuity-based business model. So while revenues in both businesses were a bit soft, we delivered overall good results in a somewhat volatile macro environment.
Total revenue of $4.2 billion was down 3% at actual currency and down 4% on an adjusted constant currency basis, including 1 point of negative currency. I'll be discussing our results on an adjusted basis when making comparisons against the prior year as the third quarter 2015 included the $389 million pretax charge, including a revenue reduction of $116 million related to our Health Enterprise strategy change.
Adjusted gross margin of 31.3% was up 10 basis points year-over-year, driven by improvements in both segments, partially offset by a greater mix of Services, which structurally has a lower gross margin. There was a modest negative transaction currency impacting quarter 3, reflecting yen strength against the euro, pound and U.S. dollar, partially mitigated by our hedging and currency risk sharing with Fuji Xerox. At current rates, we are expecting some additional pressure in quarter 4.
Adjusted RD&E was down $10 million year-over-year and adjusted SAG was down $28 million, driven by productivity and cost initiatives, which were partially offset by higher expenses related to prior year compensation and benefits reduction. Overall flow-through from our strategic transformation action resulted in good margins in both segments and a solid 9.2% total company operating margin. Adjusted other net expense was down $17 million year-over-year, driven by lower interest expense. Equity income of $39 million in the quarter was down slightly year-over-year.
Our third quarter adjusted tax rate of 25.3% was 1.8 points below last year and just under our guidance range of 26% to 28%, reflecting the geographic mix of our profits. Bottom line, adjusted earnings of $0.27 was in the middle of our guidance range and flat year-over-year.
Turning to Services. We had another quarter of very good operating profit growth, up $33 million or 17% year-over-year, a significant margin improvement, more than offset modest revenue declines. Services revenue was up 1% at actual currency, down 2% at constant currency and adjusting for the prior year Health Enterprise charge. Document Outsourcing grew 1% year-over-year with growth continuing to be driven by Xerox Partner Print Services. 
BPO declined 4% on an adjusted basis, reflecting our continued focus on profitability, very modest inorganic contribution as well as foregone revenue associated with the Health Enterprise strategy change. Within BPO, public sector revenue grew 3% as our transportation business continues to perform well and is benefiting from ramping new business, while commercial industries and health care declined driven by headwinds as we prioritize profitability, and therefore, have stepped away from some unprofitable contracts.
Total signings in the quarter were up 17% year-over-year and are up 6% for the trailing 12 months. The increase in quarter 3 was driven by strong renewal, a reflection of both high renewal opportunity as well as a good renewal rate of 86%, confirming the value we provide our customers. Over the past year, we have renewed 8 of our 10 top BPO clients. New business signings have been lower over the past year as we have strengthened our signings criteria, setting the bar higher on price, margin and deal terms. An important measure of our progress this year is services margin. This has been an area of intense focus, and the team delivered a quarter 3 margin of 9.4%, at the high-end of our 8% to 9.5% full year range. This strong performance reflects broad contribution across BPO, a result of both our strategic cost transformation initiatives and increased operating discipline by the team. And as we've said before, Document Outsourcing margin generally is in line with the Document Technology segment margin.
So key takeaways from Services are consistent with what we said in quarter 2. While revenue was a bit soft, Document Outsourcing remains a good performer; and in BPO, we're making steady progress improving profitability. There's been a near-term trade-off between revenue growth and margin. But overall, it has resulted in strong profit growth and will provide a solid foundation for our businesses as we prepare to separate.
Document Technology delivered strong margins in the face of ongoing revenue pressures within a tough market environment. Revenue was down 9% at actual currency and 7% at constant currency, with equipment down 13% and annuity down 5%. Annuity was an improvement from quarter 2 driven by supplies.
Within equipment, trends improved in both entry and high end, reflecting new product introduction, but mid-range lagged due to lower large account sales in the U.S. When we include Document Outsourcing with Document Technology, revenue declined 5% in the third quarter and is down 4% year-to-date. Overall, we continue to maintain our equipment revenue market share leadership.
Turning to activity. We delivered good growth across all color activity segments with particular strength in high end due in part to the recent drupa trade show. Entry results benefited from better performance in developing markets where we've lapped economic weakness in some geographies. Mid-range had a mixed quarter with continued good growth from the i-Series products launched earlier this year but weakness elsewhere.
Document Technology margin of 13.1% was quite strong, up 50 basis points sequentially, reflecting strategic transformation benefit and within the middle of our full year range. Year-over-year, margin was down 80 basis points as gross margin improvements were not enough to offset a higher SAG ratio. The third quarter 2015 results included materially lower compensation and benefits expense, which we did not expect would repeat. Transaction currency in the quarter was a relatively modest 30 basis point headwind to margin and at current rate could be about twice that level in quarter 4.
So overall for Document Technology, we continued to manage the impact of revenue decline through ongoing productivity actions resulting in strong segment margins and cash generation.
And as I wrap up on the segments, I'll repeat what I said last quarter: we will manage our strategic transformation focus, and we expect continued good profitability in both Document Technology and in services as we prepare to separate.
Moving to cash flow. Operating cash generation of $370 million was strong, up $99 million year-over-year, and reflects the underlying cash generative profile of our business model. From a year-over-year perspective, good working capital performance and solid net income more than offset the impact of this year's unique Health Enterprise settlement and separation payment, which were $39 million and $21 million, respectively, in the quarter.
We've generated $522 million of operating cash during the first 3 quarters of the year, with all 2016 Health Enterprise settlement payments now behind us. Therefore, we enter quarter 4, our seasonally strongest cash flow quarter, well positioned to deliver on our guidance of $950 million to $1.2 billion for the full year. Investing cash flows were a use of $69 million and included $73 million spent on CapEx. Cash flow from financing was an $84 million use and includes $85 million for preferred and common stock dividends. Our cash balance at the end of the quarter was $1.4 billion and continues to provide us flexibility as we move into quarter 4 and prepare for separation.
Turning to our capital structure and capital allocation. We ended quarter 3 with $7.4 billion, of debt, a level we've been at all year. Applying 7:1 leverage to our customer financing assets, our allocated financing debt at the end of the quarter was $3.8 billion, leaving core debt at $3.6 billion.
