We continue to manage our capital structure to maintain credit metrics consistent with our investment-grade credit rating. On October 11, we filed an amendment to the Conduent Form 10 that included details of its anticipated post-separation capital structure. We indicated that Conduent expected to be capitalized with approximately $2.4 billion of debt and $400 million of cash and to transfer $2.05 billion of proceeds to Xerox, which we intend to use to reduce Xerox debt.
Consistent with our expectation, Xerox credit ratings remain investment grade, and we expect that the Conduent capital structure would result in a high noninvestment-grade rating.
And to touch on capital allocation. We've paid $79 million in common stock dividends in quarter 3. We completed a $13 million dealer acquisition earlier this month, consistent with our strategy to expand our U.S. Global Imaging business. And as we've said previously, as we prepare for our separation later this year, we're not planning to repurchase any shares.
Before I move to guidance on the next slide, I want to mention that Conduent will be filing its third quarter results in the next few weeks. The Conduent carve-out financials will reflect margin improvement, although not to the same degree as the Services segment since Conduent results include the student loan business, which resides in our Other segment. That business is in runoff and declined profit year-over-year as anticipated.
I'll now share with you our fourth quarter and full year expectations. For quarter 4, we expect adjusted earnings in the range of $0.32 to $0.35 and GAAP earnings of $0.11 to $0.14. For the full year, we continue to expect total revenues to decline 2% to 4% at constant currency. We're narrowing our adjusted earnings guidance range to $1.11 to $1.14, which incorporates our fourth quarter expectation.
In Services, we expect full year revenue will be flat to down 1% and margin will be at the very high end of the 8% to 9.5% range. We expect Document Technology revenues will be at the lower end of the full year range and that margin will be in line with our 12% to 14% expectation.
We expect full year GAAP earnings of $0.45 to $0.48. We continue to anticipate full year restructuring of about $300 million, including approximately $70 million in the fourth quarter and our estimate of pretax separation costs remains $175 million to $200 million and $40 million to $50 million in tax-related friction costs.
Turning to cash flow. As I mentioned earlier, our year-to-date performance positions us well for the full year and we are maintaining our expectations of $950 million to $1.2 billion for operating cash flow and $600 million to $850 million for free cash flow.
And finally, our capital allocation expectations remain largely unchanged, although we now expect to spend about $30 million to $50 million on acquisition.
So in summary, despite a somewhat challenging macro backdrop, we are on track and remain committed to delivering our overall revenue, earnings and cash flow guidance.
With that, Ursula, I'll turn it back to you.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Leslie. In summary, we are pleased with our results in the third quarter, which were in line with our expectation and driven by our ongoing operational and cost discipline. We are on track to deliver on all of our objectives for the year and es
componenttext:
Thank you, Leslie. In summary, we are pleased with our results in the third quarter, which were in line with our expectation and driven by our ongoing operational and cost discipline. We are on track to deliver on all of our objectives for the year and establish 2 companies that will be well positioned to drive shareholder value over the long term.
Before we open the line for questions, I would like to note that today has particular significance for Xerox, as this will be our last earnings call as a combined entity. Next time we report earnings, we will be 2 separate companies, each on their own path to enhance value for our clients, employees, investors and other stakeholders.
I look forward to watching both Xerox and Conduent prosper in the future.
We will now open up the line for questions. Jennifer?

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ursula. Joining us today are Jeff Jacobson, head of our Document Technology business and CEO of new Xerox following separation; Ashok Vemuri, Chief Executive Officer, Xerox Business Services and CEO of Conduent post-separation; and Brian Webb-Wals
componenttext:
Thanks, Ursula. Joining us today are Jeff Jacobson, head of our Document Technology business and CEO of new Xerox following separation; Ashok Vemuri, Chief Executive Officer, Xerox Business Services and CEO of Conduent post-separation; and Brian Webb-Walsh, CFO, Xerox Services who will be CFO of Conduent post-separation. 
Before we get to your questions, let me point out that we have several supplemental slides at the end of our deck, which provide more financial details to support today's presentation and complement our prepared remarks. [Operator Instructions] At the end of our Q&A session, I will turn it back to Ursula for closing comments.
Operator, please open the line for questions now.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of George Tong from Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of George Tong from Piper Jaffray.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ashok, first of all, welcome to Xerox. Understanding more details will be provided at the upcoming Analyst Day, Ashok, can you provide or touch on what your top 3 strategic priorities are to improve growth and margin performance in the BPO business?
componenttext: Ashok, first of all, welcome to Xerox. Understanding more details will be provided at the upcoming Analyst Day, Ashok, can you provide or touch on what your top 3 strategic priorities are to improve growth and margin performance in the BPO business?

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Sure, George. I think the focus for us continues to be to drive profitable growth. We have demonstrated a very strong margin performance. We continue to invest in the strategic transformation to turn the business, so that we are invested and investin
componenttext: Yes. Sure, George. I think the focus for us continues to be to drive profitable growth. We have demonstrated a very strong margin performance. We continue to invest in the strategic transformation to turn the business, so that we are invested and investing in areas that are our traditional strength. We have certain areas where we would like to continue to drive a higher degree of transformation, especially customer care. But we're pleased with the progress that we have made on the margin front, and I think that will give us the momentum to be able to continue to drive the transformation that we seek in our business.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very helpful. And the earnings release this quarter disclosed that work to implement the Health Enterprise platform in New York has been elongated and could result in material increases and future costs to complete. Can you help frame or quantify the pote
componenttext: Very helpful. And the earnings release this quarter disclosed that work to implement the Health Enterprise platform in New York has been elongated and could result in material increases and future costs to complete. Can you help frame or quantify the potential cost overruns and comment on your desire to remain in the government health care business given some of the recent difficulties in ramping contracts in the segment?

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we are working in a very collaborative fashion with the state. The good news is that we have learned sort of our lessons and have gained some experience based on our prior implementations. We're working closely with the state. We are making progre
componenttext: Yes. So we are working in a very collaborative fashion with the state. The good news is that we have learned sort of our lessons and have gained some experience based on our prior implementations. We're working closely with the state. We are making progress on the implementation. And given that these contracts and implementations are usually long tenor and have changing requirements and ups and downs, I think we are, given all of that, making very decent progress.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Shannon Cross from Cross Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Shannon Cross from Cross Research.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have 2 questions. The first is for Jeff. Just how do we think about what's going on in the underlying business in the printing business. I mean, equipment was down 13% in Doc Tech. I think combined, it was -- I don't know what equipment was down but ove
componenttext: I have 2 questions. The first is for Jeff. Just how do we think about what's going on in the underlying business in the printing business. I mean, equipment was down 13% in Doc Tech. I think combined, it was -- I don't know what equipment was down but overall, the sort of printing business was down about 5% constant currency when you add in Document Outsourcing. So I'm just curious, just sort of how you see the competitive landscape. The yen has obviously moved significantly. Your competitors in Japan are not reporting particularly good numbers. So what are you seeing out there as you sort of head into '17? And then I have a question for Ashok.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Shannon. Thanks very much. So first, let me address it from a global market and macro standpoint. So the global market environment continues to be challenging. As you mentioned, Shannon, there are uncertainties with currencies fluctuating in the yen
componenttext: Sure, Shannon. Thanks very much. So first, let me address it from a global market and macro standpoint. So the global market environment continues to be challenging. As you mentioned, Shannon, there are uncertainties with currencies fluctuating in the yen and the pound. Certainly, these -- the uncertainty of the presidential election in the U.S., the Brexit adds a certain degree of uncertainty in the U.K. and Europe. But these complexities are obviously what we deal with all the time. And the important thing are the counter measures. So what we're doing is we're very aggressive on the productivity measures to drive down our total delivered costs and enhance the operating margins. As you know, what we've done over the last couple of years has been pretty aggressive on productivity, and we're taking that to the next level. We're very focused on innovation and defending our market share. And we're focused on the growth areas. So specific to this quarter, what I'd say, our revenue was in line and was stable in this challenging market environment. You're correct that we were pressured on the equipment side, and some of that was more in the high-end and government bids due to these uncertainties. But we're also pleased with the annuity business driven by supplies, and we're also pleased on the high end. We saw the impact of drupa, which will benefit us for the next couple of quarters. And then at the end of September, we obviously had Graph Expo in the U.S. and we think that will benefit us. So overall, in line, good color installs and pressure on more the mono side as we're moving more sort of color in the macro environment.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then, Ashok, can you talk a bit about how you think about the balance between revenue and margin? Because over the last 3 years, Xerox has sort of bounced between wanting a lot of revenue growth out of BPO but then that's obviously an impact to
componenttext: Great. And then, Ashok, can you talk a bit about how you think about the balance between revenue and margin? Because over the last 3 years, Xerox has sort of bounced between wanting a lot of revenue growth out of BPO but then that's obviously an impact to margin depending on what you sign versus sometimes saying, no, we're going to focus more on margin, and therefore, we saw revenue declines and impact to billings -- or bookings. So just sort of philosophically, how do you think about -- I know it's a balancing act -- but what do you put more weight to?

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Shannon, my philosophy on this is we need profitable growth. Revenue growth is important in order to demonstrate that the investments are in the right place and we are continuing to provide value to our clients. Margin is an indicator of 2 things for m
componenttext: So Shannon, my philosophy on this is we need profitable growth. Revenue growth is important in order to demonstrate that the investments are in the right place and we are continuing to provide value to our clients. Margin is an indicator of 2 things for me. One is the value that our clients perceive that we are bringing to the table and are willing to pay for it. And secondly, it's a report card on our -- on management's ability to effectively and efficiently run a business. So both of these are important for the reasons I just described. And I think even though there's a certain degree of elasticity between them, it is important to manage that elasticity in a way that we see growth on both fronts.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Tien-tsin Huang from JPMorgan Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Tien-tsin Huang from JPMorgan Securities.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to dig in here just on the revenue coming in somewhat soft. I know the profitability came in nicely. But just how much of the -- you think is macro versus your profitability focus versus maybe, I guess, distractions from the split or the spin.
componenttext: Just wanted to dig in here just on the revenue coming in somewhat soft. I know the profitability came in nicely. But just how much of the -- you think is macro versus your profitability focus versus maybe, I guess, distractions from the split or the spin. Can you maybe rank those?

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll start on the services side with Ashok and then switch a little bit to the tech side with Jeff.
componenttext: We'll start on the services side with Ashok and then switch a little bit to the tech side with Jeff.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So I think what we have seen in terms of the margin improvement is clearly the flow-through of all the strategic transformation activities that we've been doing. There's a higher degree of discipline that we have driven. We have balanced some of the
componenttext: Okay. So I think what we have seen in terms of the margin improvement is clearly the flow-through of all the strategic transformation activities that we've been doing. There's a higher degree of discipline that we have driven. We have balanced some of the revenue reduction because we are being much more selective in terms of the deals we are doing. Deal qualification has improved. The bars that we have put in terms of pricing and the kind of deals that we want to do, we've raised that. So margins, as I've said, in answer to the previous question, is extremely important for us. So we need to balance that by also driving revenue growth.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I think from the tech standpoint, when you see the equipment revenue, that would tend to be impacted more by uncertainties and the macro issues. We're very fortunate from the standpoint that 75% of our business is annuity, which provides a strong
componenttext: Yes. And I think from the tech standpoint, when you see the equipment revenue, that would tend to be impacted more by uncertainties and the macro issues. We're very fortunate from the standpoint that 75% of our business is annuity, which provides a strong foundation, strong base. We're also very fortunate that the vast majority of our contracts are bundled contracts with suppliers, which provides stability for us. So what we're doing is we're not getting out ahead of our headlights. We're managing our cost and productivity very strongly, and we're looking for the opportunities to grow certainly in Document Outsourcing, Graphic Communications and in some underpenetrated markets for us such as SMB.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ananda Baruah from Brean Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ananda Baruah from Brean Capital.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Really, my question right now, I have one. It's really for Jeff and maybe for Ursula on the Xerox side. As we think about where the opportunities for incremental efficiencies could be as you get post-split and then as we think about where the opportunitie
componenttext: Really, my question right now, I have one. It's really for Jeff and maybe for Ursula on the Xerox side. As we think about where the opportunities for incremental efficiencies could be as you get post-split and then as we think about where the opportunities for, I guess, increased velocity around decision-making could be post-split, how should we be thinking about it? What things have you guys learned about those opportunities so far? And understanding, you probably don't have numbers to give us yet. I guess, from a magnitude perspective -- I, guess from -- what context in terms of -- like how should we think about it in terms of potential to be impactful on the P&L? Like what's the right context there as well? And that's it, would love your thoughts there.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So sure, Ananda. Thanks very much. And certainly, we'll cover a lot more of the details at the investor conference. But the way we look at it is this, if you look at the strategic transformation we announced over a 3-year period as a combined entity,
componenttext: Yes. So sure, Ananda. Thanks very much. And certainly, we'll cover a lot more of the details at the investor conference. But the way we look at it is this, if you look at the strategic transformation we announced over a 3-year period as a combined entity, about $2.4 billion, and we said that tech would be about 2/3 of that. So we -- the linchpin to our strategy is driving that strategic transformation very hard. And the reason is this: In past years, basically, we've offset the headwinds of annuity, price erosion and done just enough. What we want to do now is take this to a totally another level, so that we can reinvest back in the business, bring some back down to the bottom line and invest in some of the growth areas we see, certainly, in Document Outsourcing, Graphic Communications and being able to invest a little more into entry. And we'll talk a little bit more about that at Investor Day. In terms of the strategic transformation, we're driving it very hard. We're looking at things such as supply chain optimization, technical service excellence with remote call assist, remote connectivity, real estate optimization, how we can design our products with more efficiency and then delayering and simplifying the organization. So we have a pretty detailed plan, we're tracking very well towards it, and we're pleased with where we are right now.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I have -- that's really helpful, Jeff. I got a quick follow-up to that, if I could. Are those moves -- the nonrevenue moves, the core organizational moves you talked to, are those incremental to business-as-usual Xerox? And if they're incremental to b
componenttext: And I have -- that's really helpful, Jeff. I got a quick follow-up to that, if I could. Are those moves -- the nonrevenue moves, the core organizational moves you talked to, are those incremental to business-as-usual Xerox? And if they're incremental to business-as-usual Xerox, would you favor the incremental op profit dollars to be dropped to the bottom line or invest it back into growth or both of those things?

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So one of the things in our message is that there's no business as usual at Xerox. So what we're going to do as we separate our companies is we're going to take all the good things that we bring from Xerox, there are a lot of great things, but we're going
componenttext: So one of the things in our message is that there's no business as usual at Xerox. So what we're going to do as we separate our companies is we're going to take all the good things that we bring from Xerox, there are a lot of great things, but we're going to be a much more simplified, delayered organization. And what we're going to do with the efficiencies we drive in taking strategic transformation to the next level, some will certainly drop to the bottom line and some of it will be invested to improve the revenue trajectory.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Essex from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Essex from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ashok, I was wondering if I could maybe ask you about the services performance. And now that you've been there for a little while and you've rolled up your sleeves, how much of the lower guidance is due to the more -- the greater degree of selectivity in
componenttext: Ashok, I was wondering if I could maybe ask you about the services performance. And now that you've been there for a little while and you've rolled up your sleeves, how much of the lower guidance is due to the more -- the greater degree of selectivity in contracts? And I notice the margins are now kind of pointed towards the high end. How much of the margin is due to your strategic transformation versus pricing?

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the margin improvements, Brian, are to a great extent driven by the efficiency that we have seen. And remember that this margin improvement that we have seen comes despite our performance in customer care, and I'll elaborate more on that as
componenttext: Well, I think the margin improvements, Brian, are to a great extent driven by the efficiency that we have seen. And remember that this margin improvement that we have seen comes despite our performance in customer care, and I'll elaborate more on that as we go into [Audio Gap}, et cetera. But clearly the -- where our business is actually clicking in and the ones that we are investing and amplifying, these are coming in at decent margins and actually much improved margins than previous period. But we still have a ways to go in terms of being able to transform some of our businesses, which are core to us. And as we do that, as we get more selective, as we drive a much more predictable and sustainable, scalable business and we have the foundation for it, I think we would be able to see the performance of that in future quarters.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And maybe as a follow-up, in terms of transforming the business again, as I think back to conversations that we previously have with Bob for example, we've talked about centralizing the legacy -- relatively distributed nature of the legacy ACS busin
componenttext: Okay. And maybe as a follow-up, in terms of transforming the business again, as I think back to conversations that we previously have with Bob for example, we've talked about centralizing the legacy -- relatively distributed nature of the legacy ACS business. I mean, how far along from previous initiatives are we? And then how much more room is there to go within that organization in terms of increasing its efficiency? Maybe if we can get a -- if we can just get a sense of your fresh take on the business and what's new in the way that you view it.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the good news is that this is not something that we've just decided or contemplated to do. This is in progress. So we've taken enough initiatives and more, if you will, on transforming the business. In some places, we've been effective. We clearly
componenttext: Yes. So the good news is that this is not something that we've just decided or contemplated to do. This is in progress. So we've taken enough initiatives and more, if you will, on transforming the business. In some places, we've been effective. We clearly have a business which is very widespread both from the range of businesses that we do, the range of clients that we have and the geographical spread. So we need to refocus ourselves on those things that we are really good at, amplify those and invest in them and continue to drive -- through the strategic transformation initiative, drive this to success. But I think the important thing is to also understand that this is not something that's going to happen overnight or in a few quarters. This is a transformation. It is going to transition over a period of time. And we will discuss the appropriate metric as we bridge from where we are to where we really want to be.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Frank Atkins from SunTrust.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Frank Atkins from SunTrust.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to ask, Ashok, what are the major levers that you see to pull to drive profitability going forward?
componenttext: I want to ask, Ashok, what are the major levers that you see to pull to drive profitability going forward?

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the number one, of course, is we have to refocus on our delivery model. Customer care is a big part of what we do. Innovation in that, either through robotics and automation, is a key part of what we do. There are some internal processes in
componenttext: Well, I think the number one, of course, is we have to refocus on our delivery model. Customer care is a big part of what we do. Innovation in that, either through robotics and automation, is a key part of what we do. There are some internal processes in how we run ourselves, which we could use some of those similar processes and tools to make us much more effective and efficient. We have to look for businesses that will provide us profitable growth. We have to exploit it and monetize all the assets that we have within the company. And we have a ton of them which we need to be deployed across the board. We have to look at businesses and segments and geographies which will help us meet those profitability goals. And in certain situations, we also have to sort of run off businesses that we're deliberately taking a view on running off.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Matt Cabral from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Matt Cabral from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask about the proposed Conduent balance sheet. I guess, on my estimates, it looks like the business will start off with north of 3x gross leverage, which seemed a little bit high relative to where some of the pure-play BPO competitors are, and
componenttext: I wanted to ask about the proposed Conduent balance sheet. I guess, on my estimates, it looks like the business will start off with north of 3x gross leverage, which seemed a little bit high relative to where some of the pure-play BPO competitors are, and given the meaningful turnaround that this business faces going forward. So I guess, what gives you the confidence that this is the right capital structure for Conduent going forward? And does this level of leverage still give you room to make either the organic or inorganic investments needed to transform this business ahead?

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Matt, it's Brian. As Ursula and Leslie both mentioned, we anticipate being a high noninvestment-grade-rated company. We believe the leverage that we're starting with is manageable. We intend to improve the leverage over time through operational perform
componenttext: So Matt, it's Brian. As Ursula and Leslie both mentioned, we anticipate being a high noninvestment-grade-rated company. We believe the leverage that we're starting with is manageable. We intend to improve the leverage over time through operational performance improvement. So again, we will use cost transformation to create room to make organic investments. The inorganic investments will be timed as we can afford them, but we believe that it's a manageable starting point.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm just going to ask one for Jeff, more on the legacy Xerox business. I guess, I wanted to ask around the USDA contract win that was mentioned in the prepared remarks. And first of all, is there any help around the ramp of that contract? And then more ju
componenttext: I'm just going to ask one for Jeff, more on the legacy Xerox business. I guess, I wanted to ask around the USDA contract win that was mentioned in the prepared remarks. And first of all, is there any help around the ramp of that contract? And then more just taking a step back and looking at that vertical in particular, around U.S. federal, was that a sort of opportunistic one-off win? Or is that an area where there might be a little bit more of a robust pipeline, particularly given the pending Lexmark acquisition that's out there?

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Matt. Not specific to the Lexmark acquisition, but I think more of the USDA win, we're very strong in federal, we're very strong in public sector. Document Outsourcing is a strong and really good business for us. We're the clear market leader
componenttext: Yes. Thanks, Matt. Not specific to the Lexmark acquisition, but I think more of the USDA win, we're very strong in federal, we're very strong in public sector. Document Outsourcing is a strong and really good business for us. We're the clear market leader, and we continue to see growth and strong margins in that business. It's an area of focused strategic importance to us. And we had a good renewal rate. We continue -- we're very strong in the large enterprise sector. We're always focused on new logos and new customers, and this was a big part of that. In addition to that, we're going to apply that same expertise, if I can call it that, to the Managed Print Services in the SMB sector as well, where we even have a lot more opportunity for growth there.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Steve Schneiderman sitting for Keith today. I wanted to direct this to Ashok. As we think about getting an update on the sales cycle, signings for the quarter were up about 15%. I understand this includes Document Outsourcing. But signings are dow
componenttext: This is Steve Schneiderman sitting for Keith today. I wanted to direct this to Ashok. As we think about getting an update on the sales cycle, signings for the quarter were up about 15%. I understand this includes Document Outsourcing. But signings are down by about the same amount, as you talked about trying to be more selective on profitable growth. My question is, where are we in this cycle in terms of churning out these low-profit potential new deals and being able to once again being able to look at a more steady space of get-signings growth?

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So from our signings growth perspective, it grew about 17%, and the bulk of that actually came from renewals. So that is actually good news. We have 8 out of our 10 BPO clients actually renewed with us. So obviously, whatever we're bringing to the pa
componenttext: Yes. So from our signings growth perspective, it grew about 17%, and the bulk of that actually came from renewals. So that is actually good news. We have 8 out of our 10 BPO clients actually renewed with us. So obviously, whatever we're bringing to the party, our clients like and they can -- they want to continue to do business with us. The area of concern, if you will, for us is new deal signings. That is down. And that is an area of focus. I called in my go-to-market team in October. We basically sat down to look at the opportunities in the market. In the spaces that we are strong in, there continues to be headroom for growth and there are opportunities out there, which we will selectively take to drive profitable growth.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Is this something, you think, can be resolved mid-2017? Or is that about a little conservative or aggressive from that perspective?
componenttext: Okay. Is this something, you think, can be resolved mid-2017? Or is that about a little conservative or aggressive from that perspective?

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's difficult to put a time line on this. But suffice it to say that we are intensely focused on driving revenue, in driving new business growth while at the same time continuing to respond to the trust our existing clients have placed in us by b
componenttext: I think it's difficult to put a time line on this. But suffice it to say that we are intensely focused on driving revenue, in driving new business growth while at the same time continuing to respond to the trust our existing clients have placed in us by bringing innovative solutions to the table.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jim Suva from Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jim Suva from Citigroup.

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have 2 questions, and I'll ask them both at the same time. First of all, as you prepare for separation, and I'm sure the ERP, your internal IT systems you have are preparing for -- there's a lot of effort ahead of that. Are you going to have a need to,
componenttext: I have 2 questions, and I'll ask them both at the same time. First of all, as you prepare for separation, and I'm sure the ERP, your internal IT systems you have are preparing for -- there's a lot of effort ahead of that. Are you going to have a need to, say, meaningfully increase your inventory just to make sure that one system doesn't accidentally not talk to another system? Or is that inventory management kind of already ironed out? And then my second question is, on the Affordable Care Act and the election, there's been a lot of talk about that and such as well as costs going up on that. Can you help us quantify what that means to Xerox? Or do we know -- or with cost going up, is that bad, is that good in enrollees or is there no impact at all? Or how should we think about the election and the Affordable Care Act of what's all going on the news?

headline: Xerox Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Jim, I should take that. This is Ursula. I haven't spoken a lot today. It's actually a good feeling. But I'll take this question. First one, on the transition and inventory and how we're looking at that. We're entering something, I talked about this in
componenttext: So Jim, I should take that. This is Ursula. I haven't spoken a lot today. It's actually a good feeling. But I'll take this question. First one, on the transition and inventory and how we're looking at that. We're entering something, I talked about this in my prepared remarks, a phase that we call soft separation. And the reason why that's important for investors is that it's a time that we can essentially practice, do a phased implementation of all of the complex separation activities and make sure that we don't stumble on -- when we're actually independent, including things like the inventory management system. Independent of the soft separation, we would have very little problem with this area. But I think the soft separation makes it such that we can actually double and triple check there. So I wouldn't -- we don't -- we're not managing inventory any differently than we normally would at the end of the year. All we're doing is making sure that as we do a separation, we don't have any fumbles, which we don't expect. As far as costs and the impact -- health care costs, the impact of ACA or any potential changes to ACA on our internal cost and the marketplace, we actually just don't see any. Internal costs, we will manage our internal health care costs in the most efficient way possible. I mean, we are a good health care provider, payer of services for our clients. Our customers haven't changed. And as far as the marketplace out there, we're not really seeing a big set of headwinds or change in the market dynamics because of any potential changes for ACA. I hope I answered both of your questions.

componenttext: So thank you for your questions. In the third quarter, we made steady progress against all 3 of our commitments: delivering on our 2016 financial goals, implementing our strategic transformation and completing the separation by year-end. We remain on track to achieve all 3. We look forward to sharing more details about the 2 companies at our Investor Days, and thank you, everyone, for joining the call.
